div.p: I Do appoint Benjamin Tooke to Print the TRYAL of Laurence Braddon and Hugh Speke; and Order that no other Perſon preſume to Print the ſame.

THE TRYAL OF LAƲRENCE BRADDON AND HƲGH SPEKE, Gent. Upon an INFORMATION OF High-Miſdemeanor, Subornation and ſpreading falſe Reports. Endeavouring thereby to raiſe a Belief in His Majeſties Subjects, that the late Earl of ESSEX did not Murther himſelf in the TOWER, contrary to what was found by the Coroners Inqueſt. Before the Right Honourable Sir George Jeffreys, KNIGHT and BARONET, Lord Chief Juſtice of His Majeſties Court of KINGS-BENCH, and the reſt of the Reverend JUDGES of that Court, holden at Weſtminſter, on Friday the 7th. of February, 1683.
LONDON: Printed for Benjamin Tooke at the Ship in S. Paul's Church-Yard, 1684.

div.head: THE TRYAL OF Laurence Braddon and Hugh Speke, Gent.

On Thurſday the Seventh of February, Anno Dom. 1683. Anno
que Reg. Caroli Secundi xxxvi. A Tryal was had at the Kings Bench Bar, in a Cauſe between our Sovereign Lord the King, and Laurence Braddon and Hugh Speke, Gentlemen; upon an Information exhibited againſt them the laſt Term, by his Majeſties Attorney General, for an High Miſdemeanor: and to which, they the ſame Term pleaded Not Guilty, and the Tryal proceeded in this manner.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: CRyer, call the Defendants, Laurence Braddon and Hugh Speke.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Laurence Braddon and Hugh Speke, come forth or elſe this Inqueſt ſhall be taken by your default.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: They appear.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Gardez votrez Challenges. Swear Sir Hugh Middleton,

div.p:
(which was done,) and there being no Challenges, the Twelve Gentlemen ſworn to try this Cauſe, were theſe.
Sir Hugh Middleton, Jur.
Thomas Harriott. Jur.
Thomas Earsby, Jur.
Joſhua Galliard, Jur.
Richard Shoreditch, Jur.
Charles Good, Jur.
Samuel Rouſe, Jur.
Hugh Squire, Jur.
Nehemiah Arnold, Jur.
John Bifield, Jur.
William Wait and Jur.
James Supple. Jur.
Who being counted, Proclamation was made in uſual form for Information.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you of the Jury hearken to the Record. His Majeſties Attorney General in this Court has exhibited an Information againſt the Defendants by the Names of Laurence Braddon of the Middle Temple, Gentleman, and Hugh Speke of Lincolns Inn, Gentleman.
And the Information ſets forth.

That whereas Arthur Earl of Eſſex, the 12th of July, in the Thirty Fifth year of the Reign of our Sovereign Lord Charles the Second, by the Grace of God, of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, King, Defender of the Faith, &c. was committed to the Priſon of our Lord the King, in the Tower of London, for certain High-Treaſons by him ſuppoſed to be committed. And the ſaid Arthur Earl of Eſſex being a Priſoner in the Tower of London aforeſaid, for the High-Treaſon aforeſaid, the 13th. day of July, in the aforeſaid Thirty Fifth Year of the Reign of our ſaid Sovereign Lord the King, that now is; not having the fear of God before his eyes, but being moved and ſeduced by the Inſtigation of the Devil, at the Tower of London, aforeſaid, in the County of Middleſex aforeſaid, himſelf feloniouſly, and as a Felon of himſelf did kill and murther, as by an Inquiſition taken at the Tower of London aforeſaid, in the County of Middleſex aforeſaid, the 14th. day of July, in the year aforeſaid, befor Edward Fernham
Eſquire, then Coroner of our Lord the King, of the Liberty of the Tower of London, aforeſaid, upon the view of the Body of the ſaid Arthur Earl of Eſſex; and now in this Court remaining of Record more plainly does appear. They the ſaid Laurence Braddon and Hugh Speke not being ignorant of the Premiſes, but contriving, and maliciouſly and ſeditiouſly intending the Government of our ſaid Lord the King of this Kingdom of England, into Hatred, Diſgrace and Contempt to bring, the 15th. day of Auguſt, in the aforeſaid Thirty Fifth year of the Reign of our ſaid Sovereign Lord the King that now is, and divers other dayes and times as well before as after, at the Pariſh of S. Clement Danes in the County of Middleſex, with force and arms, &c. falſly, unlawfully, maliciouſly and ſeditiouſly did conſpire and endeavour to make the Subjects of our ſaid Lord the King of this Kingdom of England, to believe that the Inquiſition aforeſaid was unduely taken, and that the ſaid Arthur Earl of Eſſex by certain Perſons unknown, in whoſe Cuſtody he was, was Killed and Murthered. And to perfect and bring to effect their malicious and ſeditious Contrivances aforeſaid; they the ſaid Laurence Braddon and Hugh Speke at the Pariſh of S. Clement Danes in the County of Middleſex aforeſaid, the 15th. day of Auguſt, in the Thirty Fifth year aforeſaid, falſly, unlawfully, unjuſtly, maliciouſly and ſeditiouſly did conſpire to procure certain falſe Witneſſes to prove, That the ſaid Arthur Earl of Eſſex, was not a Felon of himſelf, but that the ſaid Earl of Eſſex by the ſaid Perſons unknown was killed and murthered: And to perſwade other Subjects of our ſaid Lord the King to believe this to be true, they the ſaid Laurence Braddon and Hugh Speke, falſly, maliciouſly and ſeditiouſly, then and there in writing did declare and cauſe to be declared, the ſaid Laurence Braddon to be a Perſon that would proſecute the murther of the ſaid Earl of Eſſex; to the great Scandal and Contempt of the Government of our Lord the King of his Kingdom of England, to the evil example of all other in the like caſe offending, and againſt the Peace of our Sovereign Lord the King, his Crown and Dignity. To this Information the Defendants have ſeverally pleaded Not Guilty, and for their Tryal have put themſelves upon the Country; and His Majeſties Attorney General likewiſe, which Country you are: Your Charge is to enquire, whether the Defendants, or either of them, are Guilty of this great Miſdemeanour whereof they are Impeached, or Not Guilty? If you find them or either of them Guilty, you are to ſay ſo; if you find them, or either of them Not Guilty, you are to ſay ſo, and no more, and hear your Evidence.

div.p: Then Proclamation was made for Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dolben.
sp.p:
May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, and you Gentlemen that are Sworn, this is an Information preferred by Mr. Attorney General, againſt the Defendants Laurence Braddon and Hugh Speke, and the Information does ſet forth, That whereas Arthur late Earl of Eſſex the 12th. of July laſt, was committed to the Tower of London for certain Treaſons ſuppoſed to have been by him done: And the ſaid Earl being ſo committed Priſoner to the Tower for Treaſon, not having the fear of God before his eyes, feloniouſly and as a Felon, did kill and murther himſelf, as by an Inquiſition taken before the Coroner of the Tower-Liberty may more fully appear, yet the Defendants Laurence Braddon and Hugh Speke not being ignorant of the Premiſſes, but deſigning to bring the Government into Hatred and Contempt, the 15th. day of Auguſt laſt, at the Pariſh of S. Clement Danes in this County, with force and Arms falſly, unlawfully, maliciouſly and ſeditiouſly did conſpire together to make the Kings Subjects believe, That the Inquiſition aforeſaid was unduly taken, and that the ſaid Earl of Eſſex did not murther himſelf, but was by certain Perſons unknown, in whoſe cuſtody he was, murthered. And it further ſets forth, that theſe Defendants Laurence Braddon and Hugh Speke deſigning to diſturb and diſquiet the minds of the Kings Subjects, and to ſpread falſe reports, did conſpire to procure certain falſe Witneſſes to prove, that the ſaid Earl of Eſſex was not a Felon of himſelf, but was by ſome Perſons unknown, killed and murthered: And to perſwade other Subjects of our Sovereign Lord the King, to believe the ſaid Report, they did falſly, malitiouſly, Unlawfully and Seditiouſly cauſe to be declared in Writing, That the ſaid Laurence Braddon was the Perſon that did proſecute the ſaid Earls Murther. And this was to the great Scandal of the Government, to the evil Example of all Perſons in like caſe offending, and againſt the Peace of the King, his Crown
and Dignity. To this the Defendants have pleaded Not Guilty, if we prove it upon them, we make no queſtion you will find it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, and you Gentlemen of this Jury, Mr. Speke and Mr. Braddon, theſe two Gentlemen, are accuſed of as High Conſpiracy as ever has or could well happen in our days, of throwing the Murther of a Perſon that killed himſelf, upon the Government. And I muſt acquaint you, their deſign was of an higher Nature than barely that; for this Gentleman, my Lord of Eſſex was committed to the Tower for the late Plot, and being ſo committed, when he had killed himſelf there, that was more than a thouſand Witneſſes to open the eyes of the People, and confirm the belief of the Conſpiracy: And one would have thought, after that there had been an end of the deſign, that theſe Proteſtant Gentlemen, as they call themſelves, were carrying on; when the Earl of Eſſex a Perſon of that Quality and Worth, ſhould go to Murther himſelf upon the ſenſe of what he was Guilty of. So that the Deſign, Gentlemen, was to ſtifle the Plot, and at the ſame time they muſt throw this ill thing that the Earl had committed upon himſelf, upon the Government, that, Gentlemen, was the main diſgrace in order to ſtifle that great Evidence of the Plot. And Mr. Braddon muſt of his own head, not being put on by any of the Friends of the Earl of Eſſex, who were all very ſenſible the Earl had done this Fact, committed this Murther upon himſelf; but I ſay, he out of a true Principle to manage the Proteſtant Cauſe as they call it, but indeed it was the Plot, he becomes the Proſecutor of this buſineſs, and you will find him by the proofs in the Caſe, a man of many like Projects. For you will find him value himſelf upon theſe Titles, That he is the Proſecutor of the Earl of Eſſex's Murther, and the Inventor of the Proteſtant Flails, an Inſtrument, I ſuppoſe Gentlemen you have all heard of.

Now Gentlemen, to make this appear to the World, Letters are ſent into all Parts of England of this Bruit and Report. He himſelf goes about to find Evidence; for it was ſo great a truth, and there was ſuch a plain proof that the Earl of Eſſex had killed himſelf, that he muſt labour it to get Evidence. And he goes about it accordingly, and at length he meets with a little Child of Twelve years of Age, and he prepares for him all with his own hand-writing, a Depoſition, which is a feigned Story all of it, and in every part of it will appear to be falſe, and there he mightily ſolicits this young Boy to ſign it. He comes to his Fathers Houſe, carries him in a Coach, forces him away, and forces him to ſign this Paper that he had thus prepared for him, all of his own invention and writing; and with the like confidence as he appears here, (for ſo he does appear with very great Confidence, as you may obſerve) he atteſts it himſelf. And Gentlemen, we ſhall ſhew you, that here up and down the Town he makes it his common diſcourſe, what he was in hand with, and makes his boaſt of himſelf to be the Proſecutor of the Earl of Eſſex's Murther, and he had as good a Confederate as himſelf, Mr. Speke, and he having an Intereſt in the Country, whither the news muſt be ſent all abroad, and Mr. Braddon muſt go to pick up Evidence, I know not where a great way off of a Murther committed in the Tower. We ſhall prove to you, he had Letters Miſſive and recommendatory from Mr. Speke to a Gentleman with whom Mr. Braddon was to adviſe: for they looked upon it to be as dangerous an Enterprize almoſt as the Plot it ſelf, as indeed it was; therefore they muſt be wary, and Mr. Braddon is adviſed to go by a wrong name, ſo this Mr. Speke and Braddon were to carry on and make up this Tragi-Comedy, for I can call it nothing elſe, for the ridiculouſneſs as well as the dangerouſneſs of the Deſign. The report was to be that this Murther of the Earl of Eſſex was committed by the Officers that attended my Lord, and to fall out in time when his Majeſty was
in the Tower, as if the King himſelf had a hand in it. We ſhall trace it in all the parts of it by ſeveral Witneſſes, and hope you will make them an Example, firſt by finding them Guilty, and the Court afterwards by a ſevere Puniſhment for ſuch a villainous practice, to ſcandalize the Government with the Murther of a Noble Peer. We ſhall begin with ſhewing you the Inquiſition, or rather firſt with the Convictment of the Earl of Eſſex for High-Treaſon, becauſe that is ſaid in the Record by way of inducement.
Call Mr. Reynolds, (who was ſworn) Have you the Warrant of Commitment of my Lord of Eſſex?

sp.speaker: Mr. Reynolds,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Shew it the Court. Let the Clerk read it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Reynolds.
sp.p: This is the Commitment that was delivered the Lieutenant of the Tower, together with my Lord of Eſſex.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: This is directed to Thomas Cheek, Eſquire, Lieutenant of his Majeſties Tower of London. Subſcribed Leolin Jenkins, and dated—

body.head: Sir Leolin Jenkins, Knight, of his Majeſties moſt Honourable Privy Council, and Principal Secretary of State.
body.p: THeſe are in his Majeſties Name to will and require you to receive into your Cuſtody the Perſon of Arthur Earl of Eſſex herewith ſent you, being committed for High-Treaſon, in compaſſing the Death of the King (whom God preſerve) and conſpiring to Levy War againſt His Majeſty. And him the ſaid Earl of Eſſex to keep in ſafe cuſtody, until he ſhall be delivered by due courſe of Law. And for ſo doing this ſhall be your Warrant.
body.closer:
Given under my Hand and Seal at Whitehal the 10th. day of July, 1683.
L. Jenkins. To Thomas Cheek, Eſquire Lieutenant of His Majeſties Tower of London.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we will then read the Inquiſition, that the Earl being thus in the Tower, killed himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Shew the Inquiſition. Where is Mr. Farnham?

sp.speaker: Mr. Farnham.
sp.p: Here I am. The Inquiſition is returned here, and is upon Record.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Here it is Number 11. He reads

London. ſſ. An Inquiſition indented, taken at the Tower of London aforeſaid, in the County of Middleſex, the 14th. day of July, in the year of the Reign of our Sovereign Lord Charles the Second by the Grace of God of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, King, Defender of the Faith, &c. the Thirty Fifth; before Edward Farnham Eſquire, Coroner of our ſaid Lord the King, of the Liberty of the Tower of London aforeſaid, upon view of the Body of Arthur Earl of Eſſex, then and there lying dead; by the Oaths of Samuel Colwel, Eſquire, William Fiſher, Thomas Godſel, Eſquire, Thomas Hunt, Nathaniel Mountney, Eſq Thomas Potter, William How, Robert Burgoine, Eleazer Wickins, Thomas Hogsfleſh, Henry Cripps, Richard Rudder, William Knipes, John Hudſon, John Kettlebeter, Lancelot Coleſon, Morgan Cowarn, Thomas Bryan, William Thackſton, Richard Cliffe, Zebediah Pritchard, William Baford and Theophilus Carter, good and lawful Men of the Liberty of the Tower of London aforeſaid, who being charged and Sworn to enquire for our ſaid Lord the King, when, by what means and how the ſaid Arthur Earl of Eſſex, came to his Death, upon their Oaths do ſay, that the ſaid Arthur Earl of Eſſex the 13th. day of July, in the Thirty Fifth year of the Reign of our ſaid Sovereign Lord the King aforeſaid, at the Tower of London aforeſaid, in the County of Middleſex aforeſaid, about the hour of Nine in the Forenoon of the ſame day, not having the fear of God before his eyes, but being ſeduced and moved by the Inſtigation of the Devil, of his Malice aforethought, at the Tower of London aforeſaid, in the County aforeſaid, then and there being alone in his Chamber, with a Razor of the value of one Shilling, voluntarily and feloniouſly did cut his Throat, giving unto himſelf one Mortal Wound, cut from one Jugular to the other, and by the Aſpera
Arteria, and the Wind-Pipe to the Vertebres of the Neck, both the Jugulars being throughly divided, of which ſaid mortal Wonud, the ſaid Arthur Earl of Eſſex inſtantly died; And ſo the Jurors aforeſaid ſay upon their Oaths, that the ſaid Arthur Earl of Eſſex, in manner and form aforeſaid, then and there, voluntarily and feloniouſly as a Felon of himſelf, did kill and Murther himſelf, againſt the Peace of our Sovereign Lord the King, his Crown and Dignity. In Witneſs whereof as well I the Coroner aforeſaid, as the Jurors aforeſaid, to this Inquiſition have Interchangeably put our Seals, the day and year aboveſaid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Call Mr. Evans and Mr. Edwards. After this, my Lord, we ſhall ſhew you, that Mr. Braddon went about the Town, and declared the Earl was Murthered, and he was the Proſecutor. There is Mr. Evans, Swear him (which was done.) Pray will you give an account to my Lord and the Jury, what you know of Mr. Braddon's going about and declaring he was the Proſecutor of my Lord of Eſſex's Murther?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: My Lord, All that I know of this matter is this. About the 17th. of July laſt —

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When is the Inquiſition?

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: It is the 14th. of July.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well go on.

sp.speaker: M. Evans.
sp.p: The 17th. of July laſt, I was at the Cuſtom-Houſe Key, ſhipping of ſome Lead, and the Perſon that brought me the Warrant, I told him I could not Execute it without one of the Commiſſioners Officers; and I bid him go to Mr. Edwards, who was the next Officer adjoining to the Key, and he went to his Houſe, and told him I was at the Water-ſide, and had a Warrant which I deſired him to be preſent while I Executed it, Mr. Braddon it ſeems, was then preſent in the place with Mr. Edwards when this was told him, and hearing my Name, Mr. Braddon came down with Mr. Edwards, and found me then at Smith's Coffee-Houſe, and Mr. Edwards told me, Mr. Braddon had been with him examining his Son in relation to a matter of a Razour that was thrown out of my Lord of Eſſex's window, and I preſently replied, I deſired they would not ſpeak of any ſuch matter to me, for I had ſeen the Coroners Inquiſition upon Oath, where it was declared, the thing was ſo and ſo, and two Perſons had Sworn what ſeemed to be contrary to this; and therefore I deſired they would forbear any ſuch diſcourſe to me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who they?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Braddon and he were together.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who, he? Man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Mr. Edwards. And withal I made my application to Mr. Braddon, and I deſired him he would not meddle with ſuch a matter, for I thought it might be prejudicial to him, and Mr. Edwards too. Mr. Braddon made me no anſwer, but went directly out of the Room.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you mean by ſo and ſo, and a Razour thrown out of a window? We do not underſtand your So, and So.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Relating to a matter of a Razour.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Prithee, we don't know what that matter of a Razour is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: A Razour that was ſaid to be thrown out of my Lord of Eſſex's Window.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Tell us what the Story was, man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Mr. Edwards told me that Mr. Braddon was with him to examin his Son relating to a matter of throwing a Razour out of my Lord of Eſſex's Window: This is that he ſaid to the beſt of my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was Braddon preſent there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Braddon and Mr. Edwards were both preſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what was the diſcourſe between you? Tell us plainly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p:
Says Mr. Edwards to me, Mr. Braddon has been to examin my
Son about ſuch a matter, ſo I deſired he would not diſcourſe any thing of that matter to me, and I told him, I adviſe you not to proceed, for I told him it would be prejudicial both to him and Mr. Edwards too.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is meant by this matter? He examined my Son about a matter, and I deſired him he would not diſcourſe of this matter, What is all that matter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Holloway.
sp.p: What did you apprehend by it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: I apprehended that Mr. Braddon had been to examin Mr. Edwards's Son about ſuch a matter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What matter man?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: His diſperſing of any ſuch Report.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Report?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: A Report of throwing a Razour out of my Lord of Eſſex's window.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here is a Razour thrown out of a window, and a matter of I know not what.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Withins.
sp.p: Suppoſe a man ſhould throw a Razour out of a window, what ſignifies that?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where had he heard of that matter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: This is all I heard, my Lord, I am upon my Oath.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But I wiſh thou wouldeſt let us know, what it is thou didſt hear.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Was there no talk of a bloody Razour?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: No, not a word of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came you to be frighted then, and to be unwilling to hear of that matter, and to tell him, you thought it might be prejudicial to him and Mr. Edwards?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: I told him I had ſeen the Coroners Inqueſt, where it was proved, that the Razour lay in ſuch a place; therefore I deſired they would not ſpeak to me of any ſuch matter, and I deſired Mr. Braddon not to proceed in it, for you may do your ſelf, and Mr. Edwards too, ſome prejudice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Look you, Mr. Evans, what did you underſtand by the throwing the Razour out of the window, and giving him caution not to proceed? The Razour might be found there, what was the meaning of it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, There was a Report at the Cuſtom-Houſe, that very morning the Earl of Eſſex cut his Throat, that there was a Razour thrown out of the window.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: You did adviſe Braddon, you ſay, not to proceed in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: How came you to adviſe him ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Becauſe it might be prejudicial to him, and Mr. Edwards too.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was there no talk between Mr. Edwards, Mr. Braddon and you, that Mr. Braddon would be a Proſecutor of the Murther of the Earl of Eſſex, upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Not one word or Syllable. For Mr. Braddon ſpake not one word, good or bad: I gave an account to Secretary Jenkins, of every word that paſſed.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did not you adviſe him not to proſecute the buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: I did adviſe him not to diſperſe ſuch a Report.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Report?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Of a Razour being thrown out of my Lord of Eſſex's window.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Why, ſuppoſe there had been a Razour thrown out of the window, what then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p:
Then it was contrary to the Information and Evidence given
before the Coroner.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why ſo? why might it not be thrown out after it was found in the place where the Inquiſition ſays? Thou art a wonderful cautelous man, Where is the danger of the Report, of a Razour being thrown out of a window? there muſt be ſomething more in it, if we could but get it out of him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Will your Lordſhip be pleaſed to hear me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, I do hear thee, but I do not underſtand thee.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, I will read the words verbatim that I gave to the Secretary.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, I believe you can read, and I make no doubt you can write too, or you are not fit to be a Cuſtom Houſe Officer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: I put in this Paper to the Secretary, and will repeat what I ſaid then, as near as I can upon my Oath.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I care not a farthing what you delivered to the Secretary, tell us what thou haſt to ſay plainly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Lordſhip, I will read it what it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You may look upon your Paper to refreſh your memory, but you muſt not read it here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: If it pleaſe you, I will tell you the reaſon and occaſion I had to go to the Secretary.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I know not what occaſion thou hadſt to go to the Secretary, nor do I care what thou didſt when thou cameſt there, it may be thou madeſt three Legs, it may be never a one; what is that to us? what canſt thou ſay to the matter here before us?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: That is all I can ſay my Lord. It was an Accident that they came into my company. And I tell you the manner and the occaſion. That Perſon that brought me the Warrant, ſaying to Mr. Edwards that I was below, Mr. Braddon hearing my name named, comes down with Mr. Edwards, for he had told Mr. Edwards I was related to him, and they both came to the Coffee-Houſe, and there they began to diſcourſe about this matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Withins.
sp.p: Who began to diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Mr. Edwards.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what was it he ſaid to thee?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Mr. Edwards began thus. Says he, Mr. Evans, this Gentleman has been at my Houſe to examin my Son concerning a Report that is ſpread abroad concerning a Razour that was thrown out of the Window of the Earl of Eſſex's Lodgings, that morning he cut his Throat. I hearing of that, ſaid I, Gentlemen, I have read the Coroners Inqueſt that is in Print, and it is otherwiſe declared there: And therefore let there be no diſcourſe of any ſuch matter, for I believe no ſuch thing. And ſaid I, to that Gentleman, Mr. Braddon, pray forbear medling in any ſuch thing, for Mr. Edwards is a poor man, and has divers Children, he may be ruined, and you likewiſe may be ruined your ſelf, if you proceed any further in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: We ſhall Interpret this matter by our other Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, ſo you had need, for there is nothing to be made of this Fellows Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. North.
sp.stage: [Lifting up his hands in an unuſual manner;]
sp.p: Pray, by the Oath you have taken, when you gave that advice, did Mr. Braddon make you no anſwer?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: No, none at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: Mr. Evans, pray will you anſwer one thing?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
Pray Sir, let us have no elevation of hands. Your confidence does
not ſo well become you in a Court of Juſtice, this is not a Cauſe wherein you need uſe ſo much confidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon.
sp.p: Sir, pray anſwer, did not I—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is it you would ask him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire he may be asked, Whether I, with a Brother of his, did not come to his Country-Houſe, on the Monday immediately after my Lord of Eſſex's death, and whether at his Table there was not a Report then of a Razour being ſeen to be thrown out of my Lord of Eſſex's window?

sp.speaker: L.C.J.
sp.p: Pray ask by your Council, they are moſt proper to ask queſtions for you. Tell them what you would have asked, and do'nt make long Stories your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: Were you not in company with Mr. Braddon, the Monday after my Lord of Eſſex's death?

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: What was the Report Sir at your Table, upon the Monday next after my Lord of Eſſex's death?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: My Lord, if your Lordſhip pleaſe—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray Sir, make a ſhort and plain Anſwer to what queſtions are asked you, and let us have none of your Circumlocutions, and your diſcourſes of the matter, and the matter; but let us underſtand what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is your queſtion?

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon.
sp.p: Whether I was not upon the Monday after the Earl of Eſſex's death, at his Table, where there was a diſcourſe of a Report, that a Razour was thrown out of the window, before Murther was cried out, and concerning a Boy, which went to take it up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What a Story is here, pray ask him a fair and a ſhort queſtion, if he can remember what was ſaid at his Houſe? We are got quite to the Cuſtom-Houſe and the Coffee-Houſe again, and I know not where.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: What diſcourſe was there at your Table, Sir, the immediate Monday after the Earl of Eſſex's death, concerning a Razour thrown out of a window?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: My Lord, this to the beſt of my remembrance, is what I have to ſay, and remember of the thing, that a Gentleman being with him—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Mr. Braddon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: Where was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: In the Country.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: Where, in what Country?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: In Eſſex.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: What was the place's name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: At Wanſted, my Lord: and being there, and he plucking out a paper.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He, who?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: A Brother of mine, that that Gentleman came down with to ſee me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: His name is Mr. William Hatſell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: With whom did he come?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: With this Perſon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: With this Perſon, who is this Perſon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Mr. Braddon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why canſt thou not name him, without this wire-drawing? Thou art a moſt exact Cuſtom-Houſe Officer, I'l warrant thee, thou canſt not make a plain anſwer to a plain queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: My Lord, I beg your pardon, I do not know the methods of Court.

sp.speaker: L.C.J.
sp.p: Prithe, I care not for thy methods, nor thy matter, but deal plainly with us.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: My Brother Mr. Hatſell, came down along with Mr. Braddon to my Houſe at Wanſted in Eſſex, on the Monday after my Lord of Eſſex's death, and coming down, my Brother Mr. Hatſell, pulled out the Coroners Inqueſt upon Oath that was printed, and ſhewing of it to me, I read it, and as ſoon as ever I had read it, ſaid I, Mr. Edwards, that was at the Cuſtom-Houſe that very morning when the E. of Eſſex's Throat was cut, did declare to me upon the Cuſtom-Houſe Key, That his Son did declare, that the Razour was thrown out of the window, which ſeems to contradict this Paper, that ſays, it was found lying by him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: Was this before Mr. Braddon was with Mr. Edwards?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: I can't tell that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: Was it before Mr. Braddon and Mr. Edwards came to you to the Coffee-houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Yes, I believe it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You ſay Mr. Braddon came with Mr. Hatſel to your Houſe at Wantſtead?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Who was the Perſon that told this Story?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: He brought down the printed Paper with him, and upon plucking out that Paper and reading of it, the Story was told.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray who was the Perſon that told him it was ſo reported at the Cuſtom-houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: I made that Anſwer my ſelf immediately upon reading the Paper; for I obſerved what the Coroners Inqueſt had returned, and upon that I made this Obſervation, That it ſeemed to contradict what was declared at the Cuſtom-houſe that morning my Lord of Eſſex cut his Throat.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray who declared there that the Razor was thrown out of the Window?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: It was Mr. Edwards told me.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why conſider with your ſelf now, You ſay firſt of all Edwards and Braddon came to me to the Coffee-houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: That was at another day.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: I am ſure you ſwore ſo at firſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: With your Lordſhips Favour—

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And with your Favour too Sir. Pray will you hear me, I have heard you a great while I am ſure to no purpoſe. But conſider with your ſelf, and pray be pleaſed to reconcile what you ſay now with what you ſaid at firſt if you can. You ſay firſt of all Edwards and Braddon came to me to the Cuſtom-houſe, and found me out at the Coffee-houſe, and that Edwards ſhould ſay, Some body had been with his Son, in order to examine him about a Razor that was thrown out of my Lord of Eſſex's Window, and that you immediately cried out, Have a care of that, for that contradicts the Inquiſition that I have ſeen in Print, which declares as though the Razor was found in the Room. And after that you ſay, It was that you ſaw the Inquiſition when Hatſel came down with Braddon, and you told him of the Report at the Cuſtom-houſe▪ How came you if you had not ſeen the Inquiſition till then, to give out ſuch words at the Cuſtom-houſe, Have a care of medling with that, becauſe that contradicts the Inquiſition?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: My Lord, This was ſeveral days before that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, this Diſcourſe at Wantſtead was before that at the Cuſtom-houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: This that he now ſpeaks of is an Anſwer to Mr. Braddon's Queſtion, which was about a Diſcourſe that paſſed before this other at the Cuſtom-houſe. This that he ſpeaks of the Diſcourſe at a Coffee-houſe was afterward, but indeed he firſt ſpake of it; but theſe were two diſtinct matters at ſeveral times. This laſt of the Cuſtom-houſe was, when he had made the Examination of the Boy, as that Witneſs ſays.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Therefore I think it was fit to explain it, for it looked very inconſiſtent before, what thou ſaidſt at firſt, and what thou ſaiſt now; but if thou telleſt me thy Eſſex matter was before thy Coffee-houſe matter, it is well, otherwiſe the matter I aſſure you looked very ill.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: This is the truth, my Lord, and I can tell no more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p:
Take the Times, my Lord, and you will ſee he does ſpeak very notably. The 13th. of July my Lord of Eſſex murdered himſelf, the 14th. of July the Inquiſition was taken before the Coroner, pray what was the day
that Hatſel and this Gentleman came down to you to Eſſex?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: I can't tell that, Sir, truly; but it was before this matter of the Examination of the Boy.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But pray let me ask you one Queſtion, If your matter about the Inquiſition in the Countrey was before the matter of your cautious Diſcourſe at the Cuſtom-houſe, how came you to tell them, I heard this Report of a Razor thrown out of the Window, that morning the Earl of Eſſex cut his own Throat?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Mr. Edwards reported this ſame thing that very ſame morning to me and ſeveral others at the Cuſtom-houſe-Key.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why did you not tell us this before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, my Lord, I do not underſtand the methods of the Court.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: Mr. Hatſel gave the occaſion by pulling out the Inquiſition.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, make your Obſervations anon, let the King's Councel go on with their Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What Diſcourſe had Mr. Braddon with you then at that time when Hatſel came down with him to your Houſe you ſay, and pulling out the Inquiſition you read it, and made Anſwer, You heard at Cuſtom-houſe-Key ſuch a Report that very morning the Earl murdered himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Mr. Braddon was walking up and down the Room, I did not ſpeak it to him, but I ſpake it to Mr. Hatſel, but I believe Braddon over-heard and took notice of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Withins.
sp.p: Did he concern himſelf about it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: No, not much, I did not hear him ſay any thing, but he walked up and down the Room.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Now after all this Diſcourſe of the matter, for ought I can underſtand, the matter is but this: He ſays, Edwards before the meetings either at his Houſe in Eſſex, or at the Coffee-houſe by the Cuſtom-houſe, reported to him, as tho' the Earl of Eſſex had not murdered himſelf, but ſome body elſe had done it for him. And this was reported at the Cuſtom-houſe that morning the Earl of Eſſex cut his own Throat▪ and he hearing this Report at the Cuſtom houſe at that time, afterwards comes Braddon and Hatſel to his Houſe into Eſſex, and after Hatſel had ſhew'd him the Paper of the Inquiſition in Print, he ſaid, I heard ſome Diſcourſe from Mr. Edwards at the Cuſtom-houſe of a quite other nature, and then he ſays, Braddon and Edwards came to the Coffee-houſe, and there it was he deſired them not to talk of that matter, for, ſaid he, that contradicts the Inquiſition I ſaw before. This is the ſubſtance of what he ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And hereby it does appear, that Braddon, and Evans, and Edwards, and Hatſel, are all of a Gang.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Have you the Information he gave in to the Secretary, Mr. Att. Gen. That that was given before the Councel?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis much the ſame with what he hath ſaid now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, 'tis verbatim, as I have declared now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Only this other part of Hatſel and the meeting in Eſſex was ſpoken of ſince, that was not declared before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: No, my Lord, that I did not ſpeak of, becauſe I was not examined about it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: That was part of the Secret.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p:
No, it was common Diſcourſe with me. And I did not think any thing of it, what Mr. Edwards ſaid at the Cuſtom-houſe, was ſpoken to a great many others as well as me, and the people ſeemed to be ſurpriſed with an accompt of the thing at the firſt news of my Lord of Eſſex's death.
And if I had thought it material I could have brought a great manny that were by then; but Mr. Edwards is here brought himſelf, I ſuppoſe he will not deny it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, you ſay that very morning my Lord of Eſſex killed himſelf, Mr. Edwards diſcourſed, and made this Report to you at the Cuſtom-houſe, pray tell what the diſcourſe was? what he ſaid to you? and then tell us what time of day it was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: To the beſt of my remembrance it was about eleven a Clock; there were ſeveral perſons ſtanding together, among the reſt Captain Goodland, and ſome of the Searchers, and Mr. Edwards was there, and ſaid he, I am informed from home, That my Boy has been at home, and given an accompt to my Wife, that being in the Tower, he ſaw a hand throw a Razor out of a Window, and he named my Lord of Eſſex's Window; and this Mr. Edwards did not only tell me, but to a whole Coffee-houſe of people, this matter of fact.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Holloway.
sp.p: Did not Mr. Edwards tell you, That ſome body had been examining his Boy about that Report?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: That was the ſecond time, when Mr. Braddon and Mr. Edwards came together.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Holloway.
sp.p: Who was it had been examining his Boy did he ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Mr. Braddon he ſaid had been to examine his Son.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Holloway.
sp.p: That was after the diſcourſe at Eſſex that Braddon came to examine his Son concerning the Razor.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: Yes, it was after the diſcourſe at Eſſex, where Hatſel plucking out the Paper Evans told Mr. Braddon firſt of this Razor.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, make your defence by and by Mr. Wallop: Do not make your Remarks now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Edwards. Cryer ſwear him

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What do you ask him Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Edwards, Pray will you give the Court an account of this buſineſs; for I don't know whether you heard what that Gentleman that went out laſt ſaid, he ſays you raiſed this Story, Pray give an account what you know of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray tell what you know of Mr. Braddon's coming to your Son, and what diſcourſe he or you had about the murder of the Earl of Eſſex.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: The Report that Mr. Braddon came to enquire after, was with us ſome three days before; It was in our Family three days before, and upon the 17. of July.——

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What was the Report, Mr. Edwards, before Mr. Braddon came to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: The Report I have already declared before the Council.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But you muſt tell us too, what it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: The Report of the Boy the 13. of July about 10 a Clock, as I was informed by my Family, and by the Boy afterwards by word of mouth, was this, He comes in about 10 a Clock, ſays he, I have been at the Tower (to one of his Siſters,) and have ſeen his Majeſty and the Duke of York, and the Earl of Eſſex has cut his throat, and I ſee an hand throw a Razor out of the Window, and one came out of the houſe, a Maid, or a Woman in a white Hood and a Stuff Coat and took it up, and went in again, and then I heard a noiſe as of murder cryed out. This was the Boys Report, and more than as his Report I can't ſpeak to it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: This was your Son, was it not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes, the younger of them. The two Boys were that morning going to Merchant-Taylors School together as they uſed to do, and by the way hearing the King was in the Tower, this younger Boy that was well acquainted with the Tower, gave his elder Brother the ſlip and went into the Tower, and rambled about from place to place.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did not you examine him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: Ay, I did examine him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did not you find that he denyed it again?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: No, I did examine him, and I found no denyal of any thing at all that he had reported till Mr. Braddon came to make enquiry. Aſſoon as he came to make the enquiry, and I underſtood what Mr. Braddon's buſineſs was, I begged of him that he would not inſiſt upon it by no means; I begged of him as if I had begged for my life, but he was ſo zealous in the buſineſs, that nothing would ſatisfie him. And after I had told Mr. Braddon that which I could not deny, which was the Boys Report, I left him and went down to the Cuſtom-houſe, and ſome of my Family diſcourſed the Boy at that rate that he began to deny it, and in leſs than half an hours time recollected himſelf and began to own it again, and ſo the Boy was off and on till the time he was before the Council; and to this day he ſeems to ſtand in the denyal, whether he will do it now or no I cann't tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you acquaint Mr. Braddon, That you had found this Boy to be a lying Boy, and detected him in Lyes ſeveral times?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: May it pleaſe you Sir, I acquainted him with thus much: Said I, Mr. Braddon, As I have dealt ingenuouſly with you, to let you know what the Boy's Report was, ſo I muſt likewiſe tell you, that I cannot nor will undertake to aſſert the truth of it, and preſently upon that my Daughters told me, the Boy had many times excuſed his playing Truant by falſe Stories.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you acquaint Mr. Braddon, that your Boy was a lying Boy at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I think I did not at that inſtant of time.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How old is this Boy you talk of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: About 13 years of Age, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What do you know of Mr. Braddon's forcing your Boy to ſign any thing that he had prepared after this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: When you told him, your Boy had deny'd it, what did he ſay? was he pleaſed and ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: He was not told it by me, but ſome of my Family.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: How did he behave himſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: At the ſame time they told him he denied it, at the ſame time they told him he owned it again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: How did Mr. Braddon behave himſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: Like a civil Gentleman. I ſaw nothing elſe by him, but that he was very zealous in the Buſineſs, that is the truth of it, nothing could perſwade him to deſiſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Holloway.
sp.p: Pray did you ask Mr. Braddon, or did he tell you, what was the reaſon that he was ſo inquiſitive about this Razor, and the Report of the Boy?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards,
sp.p: As to that he told me, he would let me know the reaſon of it, which was out of conſcience.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Did not Mr. Braddon carry your Son before ſeveral Juſtices of Peace?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: Before none as I know of, not one truly to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you underſtand he had taken your Boy from your Houſe in a Coach?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: Never till he carried him into his Majeſties preſence before the Council, and I knew not that till the Boy came home.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, Have you done with him? May I ask him a Queſtion?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Ay, ask him what you will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: If I underſtand you right Sir, this Report of the Boys was that morning that the Earl of Eſſex was murdered—

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was murdered, murdered himſelf man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I mean the day of his death. Now I would ask you Sir, when that was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: The Boy's Report was this, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: I ask you not what his Report was, but when? what day it was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: The 13th. of July. That day the Earl of Eſſex cut his Throat.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: How many days after that was it when Mr. Braddon came to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: It was not till the 17th. of July.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: Had you diſcourſed of the Report of your Boy at the Cuſtom-houſe, or any where elſe, that ſame day he came to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I cannot ſay that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: Had you diſcourſed it before Mr. Braddon ſpake to you upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes, I believe I had.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Had you diſcourſed it before your Boy told you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I ſhould then indeed have been the Contriver of the Story.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: So it is like enough you were.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Had you diſcourſed it to any body before you went home to your own Houſe upon your Oath Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: Upon my Oath then I diſcourſed nothing of that nature, not a tittle of it, nor knew nothing of it, till I had it from my own Family.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you not diſcourſe of it before you went home?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: No, when I came home they told me of it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: I ask you again Sir, Did not you tell it before you came home?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: About 10. a Clock, I having heard the News of the Earl of Eſſex's cutting his Throat, at the Cuſtom-houſe, I ſtepped home, being very near to my own Houſe, and as ſoon as I came in at the Door, the Family began to give me an account what News the Boy brought in.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: That was the firſt time you heard of it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes, that was the firſt time I heard of it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And did not you diſcourſe of it till after that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Call Mr. Evans. Let him come in again then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Let Mr. Evans come in again.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Mr. Evans, I would ask you this Queſtion, There was three times that you ſay, I think, that you had diſcourſe with Edwards about the Matter, as you call it, once at Eſſex, and twice at the Cuſtom-houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: No, not in Eſſex, it was Hatſel and Braddon, my Lord, that came to him there, Edwards was not there.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When you firſt had a Diſcourſe with Edwards about this Matter, what was it that Edwards did ſay to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p:
Being upon Cuſtom-houſe-Key, and Captain Goodland and ſeveral others ſtanding upon the Key, that very morning my Lord of Eſſex's Throat was cut, about 11. a Clock Mr. Edwards came to us, being ſtanding upon the Key, and told us, That he was informed his Boy had been at the Tower, and came home and told his Mother, He ſaw a Hand throw a Razor out of a Window, and that
he went to take it up, and a Maid or a Woman came and took it up, and went in again.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Evans, did he tell you this, as if he had been at home?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: No, I think it was that he had it from home by ſome Hand or other.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I was at home.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: My Lord, at two a Clock in the afternoon, when he came again to the Cuſtom-houſe, he did tell us, he had been at home, and his Boy had told him the ſame Story.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But when he told you before he had dined, did he ſay, He had been at home?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: My Family can teſtifie I was at home between 10. and 11. a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: To the beſt of my remembrance he told me he heard ſo from home.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Before he went home, you ſay, he told you of this, and that was 10. a Clock in the morning, and about 2. of the Clock in the afternoon, he ſaid, he had been at home, and it was true.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: My Lord, I was at home.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Mr. Edwards, did you tell him ſo, or did you not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: It is like I might ſay ſo about 10. a Clock, but not before I had received the Report at home.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: I underſtood it ſo, my Lord, That he had heard from home.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: I ask you this upon your Oath, mind the Queſtion, and anſwer me plainly, Did you ſpeak to him, that you had ſuch a Report from home, or did you not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: When I told it him, I had it from home, for I brought it from home.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Nay, did you tell him you had ſuch a Report from home at 10 a Clock or no?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I told him that I had met with ſuch a Report.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: From my Family at home, for the Boy came not to me to tell it·

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Then did you ſee Mr. Evans about 2 a Clock that afternoon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: 'Tis probably I did.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you, or did you not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes, I believe I might. I beſeech your Lordſhip give me leave to ſpeak. Mr. Evans and I am converſant forenoon and afternoon every day, we have Buſineſs together.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: We have Buſineſs, my Lord, about ſhipping off Goods.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: But, my Lord, if you pleaſe, I will tell you, that is the occaſion of our being together.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Anſwer me my Queſtion, Did you or did you not tell him ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I did not acquaint him with it before I had been at home, and received it from my own Family.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Look you Sir, Don't you go about to evade the Queſtion, nor trifle with the Court, you muſt anſwer me my Queſtion directly and upon your Oath, Did you tell him you had notice from home of ſuch a Report, or no?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I did not receive notice from home, but I brought it from home.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you tell him you had it from home?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I told him I had it from my Family, who told me the Boy had made ſuch a Report.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you tell him you had it from your Boy, or received notice from home about it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I did not tell him any thing before I had been at home.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well then anſwer me this queſtion. Did you tell him in the afternoon at two a Clock, Now I have been at home and examined my Boy, and find it ſo as I told you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I examined my Boy at Dinner, and I found the Boy agreed with the Report of my Daughter, and confirmed it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: I ask you what you told Mr. Evans, not what your Boy or your Daughter told you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: It is probable I might tell Mr. Evans the ſame ſtory after dinner at Two a Clock, that I did before.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Now tell us the paſſage again, Mr. Evans, as you heard it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: To the beſt of my remembrance at two a Clock in the Afternoon Mr. Edwards came and told us he had examined the Boy, and ſays he, the Boy has confirmed all that I told you.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But before that in the Morning what did he ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: I cannot ſay exactly the time, but I think it was about 10 a Clock. There were four or five more beſides my ſelf ſtanding at Cuſtom-houſe Key, and Mr. Edwards came to us and told us, ſays he; I am informed from home, as I underſtood it, not that he had been at home, but that he heard it from home, that his Boy being at the Tower had ſeen an hand throw a Razor out of a Window.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What ſaid he at two of the Clock?

sp.speaker: Mr. Evans.
sp.p: He ſaid he had examined his Boy, and he ſaid the ſame thing, that he had told us he had heard in the morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord we are now but upon the Entrance of our Evidence, to ſhew upon what ſlender grounds, how ſlight a foundation there was for this Gentleman to undertake this Proſecution.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Edwards, pray let me ask you a queſtion, Did Mr. Braddon tender any Paper to your Son to ſign?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I was informed he did do it afterwards, but I ſaw him not do any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you never ſay that Mr. Braddon had tendred a Paper to your Son to ſign?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I do not believe I ever did ſay ſo, I do not remember any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray recollect your memory and tell us, whether you did, or did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I thank God Sir that he has given me my memory and my underſtanding, I bleſs him for it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But it were well if thou hadſt any honeſty too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: And honeſty too Sir: I have not lived theſe 39 years at the Cuſtom-houſe without honeſty. I never had my honeſty queſtioned to this day. I am ſure no body can tax me with diſhoneſty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Edwards let your anger alone for a while, and anſwer the queſtion that I ſhall ask you: Did your Son refuſe to ſign that Paper?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: He did ſign it at laſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did he refuſe to ſign it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I, do not know whether he refuſed it or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Withins.
sp.p: Did you hear that your Son refuſed it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I did hear that he had ſigned it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Withins.
sp.p: But did you hear that he refuſed to ſign it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: The Boy did not tell me he had refuſed to ſign it. I did not hear him refuſe it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p:
Thou doſt prevaricate very ſtrangely, I muſt tell thee that notwithſtanding
thy reputation of 39. years of honeſty: Prithee anſwer plainly, Did you hear at any time, that your Son had refuſed to ſign it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I did not to the beſt of my remembrance.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: That is a plain anſwer man. But thou doſt ſo ſhuffle up and down, one cannot tell what to make of what thou ſayſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: Sir I deſire to ask you one queſtion, Whether ever Mr. Braddon and you had any former acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray ſtay Sir, and if you pleaſe, ſpare your Queſtion a little, for we have not yet done with Mr. Edwards. Mr. Edwards, pray ſwer me, Did Mr. Braddon ever tell you, that he had other Informations to confirm this Report of your Son from others?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: Truly I do not remember he ſaid any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ever ſay he told you ſo? Conſider of it, and remember your former Examination.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: 'Tis like ſince he may have ſaid ſo, but not at his firſt coming.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: At his firſt coming did your Son ſign his Paper then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: No, he did not, as I am informed, I ſaw it not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: But afterwards you ſay Mr. Braddon did tell you, He had other Evidence to confirm it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: It may be he might, I can't ſay it poſitively.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You ſay he did not ſign the Paper at his firſt coming?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: No, I am informed he did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: How do you know he did ſign it at laſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: My Wife and Daughters information.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But how then can you ſay, that you never heard he did refuſe it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: My Lord, he did not tender a Paper to him to ſign till he had been 2. or 3. times there, as I have heard, it was not tendred the firſt time he came.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: I wonder how thou haſt eſcaped 39. years with ſuch a Reputation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: My Lord, I never was thought otherwiſe, nor I hope never gave any occaſion for ſuch a Thought.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: I'le aſſure thee, I do not nor can take thee for one.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I hope I have done nothing to make your Lordſhip think the contrary.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Yes, thou haſt. Thou didſt nothing but ſhuffle up and down, thou art to conſider thou art upon thy Oath, and muſt anſwer Queſtions plainly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: My Lord, I do anſwer as truely as I can.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Heark you then, Mr. Edwards, anſwer me.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Speak the truth, and nothing but the truth, that is all that is required of thee; no Court of Juſtice ought to be afraid to hear truth. Let truth come out of Gods Name.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did Mr. Braddon ever tell you, That he had other Evidence beſides your Son?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I do not remember he ſaid any ſuch thing at his firſt coming.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: How thou doſt ſhuffle again. Anſwer plainly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I ask you, whether ever he did ſay it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes, he did ſay ſo afterwards.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: I muſt ask you one Queſtion more, (for I ſee 'tis very difficult to get it out of you) Pray did he tell you, that he had other Evidence beſides your Son, before he ſigned the Paper or after?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: It was before, as I take it. I ſpeak to the beſt of my knowledg, my Lord, I can ſay no more.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p:
If thou haſt a mind to continue the Reputation thou haſt got, as
thou ſaiſt, the way is to anſwer Queſtions, and ſpeak the truth plainly, let it concern whom it will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I labour to do it, my Lord, to the beſt of my Underſtanding and Capacity.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: I would not have thee ſay a tittle more than the truth, but let the truth come out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: Now Sir, I would ask you, if they have done with you, Did you ever know Mr. Braddon before the 17th. of July? Or did you ever ſee him before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: No, I never had any knowledge of him, nor ever heard a word of him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: Mr. Edwards. The Queſtion was asked of you, Whether Mr. Braddon did ſay, There was other Evidence beſides your Son; pray when was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: He did not at the firſt time, but afterwards he did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: That was a good while after, he had been with the Boy firſt.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Make your Obſervation by and by Mr. Wallop. This is not a time for them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then where is Edwards the Boy?

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: I charge you in the preſence of Almighty God ſpeak truth Child.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: And ſo ſhould you too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Edwards.
sp.p: Be ſure to ſay nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And Child turn about and ſay, Father, be ſure you ſay nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, This is the Boy, he is very little and very young, will your Lordſhip have him ſworn? What Age are you of?

sp.speaker: William Edwards.
sp.p: I am 13 my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know what an Oath is?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Suppoſe you ſhould tell a Lye, do you know who is the Father of Lyars?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Who is it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: The Devil.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And if you ſhould tell a Lye, do you know what would become of you?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What if you ſhould ſwear to a Lye? if you ſhould call God to witneſs to a Lye, what would become of you then?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: I ſhould go to Hell-fire.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: That is a terrible thing. And therefore Child, if you take an Oath, be ſure you ſay nothing but what is truth, for no Party, nor Side, nor any thing in the World, for that God that you ſay will call you to account, and caſt you into Hell-fire, if you tell a Lye, and witneſs to a Falſhood, knows and ſees all you do, therefore have a care, the truth you muſt ſay, and nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Pull off your Glove, and hearken to your Oath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: And now remember you call God to witneſs to the truth of what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Young man, look upon that Paper, is that your Hand?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſign that?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Prithee tell the Court, how thou cameſt to ſign it?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Ay, Child be not afraid. Tell the truth, for if thou telleſt the truth, thou needeſt not be afraid, but if thou telleſt a Lye, thou haſt need to be afraid; let no body, whatever has been ſaid to thee, affright thee from telling the truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Don't be afraid of thy Father or any body, but tell plainly what thou knoweſt, and ſpeak only the truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How come you to ſign that Paper?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Mr. Braddon bid me ſign it when he had writ it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Heark thee Child, Did he take it from thee what he writ, or did he write it from himſelf? Come hither Child, be not afraid, no body here will do thee any hurt.

p.hi: Then the Boy was lifted up upon the Table before the Judges.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Look upon that Paper, didſt thou put thy Name to that Paper, Child?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Whoſe Hand-writing is that Paper beſides thy Name?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Mr. Braddon's.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did he bring it ready written?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: He writ in our Parlour.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How came he to write it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: He ſaid it was for the Earl of Eſſex to give to his Wife.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And what did he ask thee before he writ that?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: He asked me, whether I ſaw any thing at the Tower, and ſo I told him, Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Ay, tell us what you told him, and be not afraid Child, but tell the truth.

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: I told him I was in the Tower, and ſaw a Razor thrown out of a Window.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: You told him ſo, and then what ſaid he to you?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: He bid me ſpeak the truth.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was that all the words you had?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: I afterwards went with my Brother into the Tower, and I ſhewed my Brother the Place, and then afterwards Mr. Braddon writ this, and he ſaid it was to give to the Counteſs of Eſſex.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Holloway.
sp.p: Did he read it to you after he had writ it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Holloway.
sp.p: And did he ask thee, whether it were true?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And didſt thou tell him it was true?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And didſt thou tell him all that was in that Paper was true?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you tell him all that was writ in that Paper before he writ it down.

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Prithee mind the Queſtion, and ſpeak truth, Didſt thou tell him all that was in that Paper before he writ it down?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes, I told him, and ſo he writ it down.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Holloway.
sp.p: You heard it all read to you, you ſay?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Then I ask you again, Did you tell him all that was in that Paper that was read to you, before he writ it down?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And after you had told him, he writ it down?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: I told him as he writ it down.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And after ſuch time as he had writ it down, did he read it to you?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And then you put your Name to it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I pray, my Lord, he may be asked this Queſtion, Whether or no when he firſt brought it in, the Boy did not deny to ſign it?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did he bring the Paper thither before thou ſignedſt it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: It was upon the Table.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Didſt not thou refuſe to put thy Name to it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: I was afraid.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: For fear of coming into danger.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why, what danger could there be? There was no danger if it was truth.

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: That was not the truth.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Which was not the truth? Was not the Paper that he had written, truth?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How ſo, Child? Was not that thou toldeſt him the truth?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Tell the truth now then.

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: So I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then he offered it firſt to you, and bid you ſign it, and you denied to put your hand to it, becauſe it was not true?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And how long after did he offer it to you again?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: A little while after.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But did you tell Mr. Braddon it was not true, when you refuſed to ſign it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why didſt thou refuſe to ſign it then?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: I was afraid becauſe it was not true.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Didſt not thou tell Mr. Braddon it was not true?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: I did not tell Mr. Braddon it was not true.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why then waſt thou afraid to ſign it becauſe it was not true at one time, and yet didſt ſign it tho' it was not true, at another time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Child, Didſt thou give Mr. Braddon any reaſon, why thou didſt not ſign it at that time?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: How didſt thou come to ſign it? Did any body ſpeak to thee between that firſt time thou refuſedſt to ſign it, and the ſecond time thou didſt ſign it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: He would fain have got my Aunt to have ſigned it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Thou ſayſt thou didſt firſt refuſe it, becauſe it was not true?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And then afterwards thou didſt ſign it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Then I ask thee, who perſwaded thee to ſign it after that time that thou firſt refuſedſt it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: My Mother was afraid to have me ſign it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Who perſwaded you to ſign it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Mr. Braddon ſaid, there was no harm in it, ſo I did it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did Mr. Braddon then perſwade you to ſign it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: He ſaid there was no harm in it, that was all.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you do it at his deſire?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And you refuſed it at firſt when he deſired it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What, becauſe it was falſe?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why then wouldſt thou ſign it afterwards, if ſome body did not perſwade thee to it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: He told me there was nothing of harm in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Hadſt thou any money offered thee by Mr. Braddon?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Hadſt thou any money promiſed thee?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Hadſt thou any thing elſe offered or promiſed thee?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: No, nothing at all.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You have heard what he has ſaid, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: No, my Lord, we have not heard a word.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p:
Then I will tell you what he has ſaid exactly. He ſays that Mr. Braddon writ it from him; that he writ it in the Room while he was there; that after ſuch time as he had writ it, Mr. Braddon read it to him: He ſays, that he had carried his Brother to ſhew him the place where he aſſigned that the Razor was found in the Tower, he ſays, that after ſuch time as the Writing was finiſhed, Mr. Braddon offered it him to ſign, and he refuſed
to ſign it, and I asked him the reaſon why, and he ſays becauſe it was falſe; he ſays ſome ſhort time afterwards Mr. Braddon came to him again.

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: No, Sir, it was the ſame time.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, the ſame time Braddon was at him again, and told him there was no harm in it, and therefore deſired him to ſign it, and becauſe he would not, he would have had his Aunt to have ſigned it; and he ſays, that Braddon telling him there was no harm in it, he did ſign it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: But withal he ſays that it is falſe.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Ay, he ſwears now 'tis all falſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: Did you tell Mr. Braddon it was falſe?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: No, he ſays he did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: Did your Siſter at all diſcourſe with you after you had dictated to Mr. Braddon? Pray what diſcourſe had you with her, after Mr. Braddon writ that Paper, before you refuſed to ſign it?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do not ask any leading Queſtion, Sir, but propoſe a fair plain Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: Did you diſcourſe with your Siſter at all, after Mr. Braddon had been at your houſe?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes, I had been at School, and when I came home they ſaid that a Gentleman that came from the Earl of Eſſex's Brother, had been to inquire of the truth of the Report I had raiſed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: What did your Siſter ſay to you?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: That was all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did ſhe name the Gentleman, and did you ſee him afterwards?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Who was it?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: That Gentleman, Mr. Braddon.

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: My Lord, We don't hear a word he ſays.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: He ſays, he had been at School, and when he came home, they told him a Gentleman came from the Earl's Brother, to inquire of the truth of what he had reported: It was asked him who the Gentleman was, and he ſays it was that Gentleman Mr. Braddon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: Before ſuch time as Mr. Braddon came to you, what did you tell your Father about this Razor, and when?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: Sir, I told him the King and Duke of York were at the Tower, and while I was there, I ſaid I ſaw a Hand caſt out a bloody Razor, and a Maid come out and take it up, and go in again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: Did you ſee any ſuch thing as a Bloody Razor caſt out?

sp.speaker: Will. Edwards.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What a duſt has ſuch a trivial Report made in the world! Admit the Boy had ſaid any ſuch thing, what an Age do we live in, that the Report of every Child ſhall blow us up after this rate? It would make a body tremble to think what a ſort of people we live among: To what an heat does Zeal tranſport ſome people beyond all reaſon and ſobriety? If ſuch a little Boy had ſaid ſo, 'tis not an half-penny matter, but preſently all the Government is to be libell'd for a Boy, which whether he ſpeaks true or falſe is of no great weight, and he ſwears 'tis all falſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, We ſhall next call Dr. Hawkins's Son of the Tower. Where is Thomas Hawkins?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen
sp.p: My Lord, Agreeable to what the Boy has now ſaid, to ſhew you that what Mr. Braddon got him to ſign was all falſe, here is the young man that truanted with him the ſame morning, that was with him all the time, the whole morning, that ſays there was no ſuch thing, and he ſaw no ſuch thing; and how could it enter into the Boys head ſuch a malicious lye, if it had not been dictated. Pray, Mr. Hawkins, will you acquaint my Lord and the Jury, whether you play'd Truant that morning with this other Boy, and where you were.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Ay, Tell the truth in Gods name, Young Man, be it one way or t'other, let the truth come out.

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: In the morning, Sir, I met with him at the Tower, going round with the King, and we walked round the Tower as long as the King walked, and then the King going into the Conſtables houſe, we and ſome more Boys were playing—

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Prithee ſpeak out, as though thou wert at play at Chuck-farthing.

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: After we had been at play, I went home, and after I had been there a little while, news was brought to my Father, that the Earl of Eſſex had killed himſelf. My Father went down, and I followed him, and after I had been there a little while, William Edwards came home, and there we ſtood looking up at the Window an hour or two at leaſt, and after we had tarried there a great while, I went out of the Tower Gate a little after 11.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was there no Razor thrown out of the Window?

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: No, there was no Razor thrown out.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Didſt not thou ſee a Razor thrown out of the Window? and a Maid come and take it up?

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: No, there was no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you there before Edwards came?

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: Yes,

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And you went out with him?

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you and Edwards go away together?

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: Did he tell you of any ſuch thing?

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What time of the day was it that you went out of the Tower?

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: Almoſt 11 a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: The Boy does ſay, he did tell his Father and Mother, and all the Family of it. And 'tis plain by the Father that it was known in the Family by 10 of the Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was this young man with you all the time that you was there, Edwards?

sp.speaker: William Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did not you tell your Father of this Story when you came from the Tower?

sp.speaker: William Edwards.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And that was the ſame time you came out of the Tower with Hawkins?

sp.speaker: William Edwards:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And you Hawkins, was this young man with you all the time you were at my Lord Eſſex's Window?

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: He came thither while I ſtood there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, This is but the beginning of our Evidence, your Lordſhip ſees what a fine Caſe it is, and how all this noiſe and buſtle has come to be made in the World. The Rumour firſt did ariſe in a Fanatick Family, and was propagated by that Party.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jones.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis eaſily known whence it came.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Gentlemen, pray will you go on with your Evidence, and make no deſcants.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: You Hawkins, when you came from your Fathers houſe, did you find that Boy in the Tower?

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: Yes Sir, a going round with the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That was before this thing happened.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: Were you with him all the while he was in the Tower?

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: Juſt before my Lord Eſſex cut his Throat I went home.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: Were you with him all the time or no? And how long were you with him?

sp.speaker: Hawkins.
sp.p: I went with him round the Tower with the King. And after we were at play, and then I went home, and then when I had been at home a little time, the rumour and noiſe came that the Earl of Eſſex had killed himſelf, ſo I went with my Father and ſtood before the Window, and I tarried there a while before he came home, and I ſtayed with him looking at the Window a great while, and we went out of the Tower together.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke.
sp.p: You little Boy Edwards, was this Mr. Hawkins with you all the time that you were in the Tower?

sp.speaker: William Edwards.
