sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Two ſhrieks or two groans, I can't well remember which.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How high was the Window?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Not above one pair of ſtairs high.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How high from the Ground might it be?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Not above one Story.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: Where abouts in the Tower was it?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Sir, it was a you go upon the Mount.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: Whoſe Lodging do you think it was?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: I did not know whoſe it was, but Folks ſaid it was the Earl of Eſſex's.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who did you tell this to?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: I told no body till I came to my Aunt, and I told her.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is her Name?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ever tell this to that Man?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Yes, afterwards I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came he to enquire of you about it?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: He came and asked me, and I could not deny it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, but how came he to ask you?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: There was a Gentlewoman that was at our houſe, and ſhe heard of it, and ſpake of it at a Gentlewoman's at Dinner, and ſo he came to our houſe to inquire about it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who is that Gentlewoman? what is her Name?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Let me ſee the Information of this Girl, that Mr. Braddon had taken.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, there it is.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know my Lord of Eſſex's Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: They ſaid it was his.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you know it of your own knowledge?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: No, Sir, I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon.
sp.p: Pray what became of the Razour that was thrown out of the Window, after it was thrown out?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: I ſaw a Woman in a white Hood come out, but I did not ſee her take it up.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Girl, you ſay that when you were at this place in the Tower, and ſaw this matter, there were a great many people there beſides your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did the Razour fall among the people that ſtood there, or did it fall out in the ſtreet, or how?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Sir it fell within the Pales.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: And was the Paſſage eaſy into the Pales?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen
sp.p: What they muſt climb over muſt they?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: No, you need not climb over, there is a door to go in. And when people went in the Souldier opened the door.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Who went in with the Souldier? Did you ſee any body go in?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: There was a Man went in, but I know not who he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did the Souldier ſtand at the door when this Razour was thrown out?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: I can't tell that, a Souldier uſed to be at the door.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: The Woman came out of the Lodging did ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Yes·

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did ſhe go in again?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: I did not ſee her go in again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did ſhe go into the Pale?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: I did not ſee her go into the Pales.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee the Razour after it fell upon the ground?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was it bloody?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Very bloody?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee no body take it up?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: No I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Come hither Child, are you ſure it was a Razour or a Knife?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: I am ſure it was a Razour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was it open or ſhut?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: It was open.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol Gen.
sp.p: What colour was the handle?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sir I can't tell, I ſee it but as it flew out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was it all over Bloody?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: All but a little ſpeck?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: It was very Bloody.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Bleſſed God, what an Age do we live in! Girl you ſay you did not know it to be my Lord of Eſſex's Window.

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: No, but as they told me.

sp.speaker: L. C J.
sp.p: Nor you did not ſee any body take up the Razour.

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But are you ſure you did not?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: I am ſure I did not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But Child, recollect thy ſelf, ſure thou did'ſt ſee ſome body take it up.

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: No, I did not;

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I ask thee again, did'ſt not thou know it to be my Lord of Eſſex's Window?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: No, but as they told me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you hear no body ſpeak to the Maid that came out?

sp.speaker: Lode.
sp.p: No body at all.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, Prithee is that thy Hand Child? ſhew her the Paper, the uppermoſt part of it.

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Sir, I can't Write.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who put thy Name to it?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Sir, I don't know no more than the Pope of Rome.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Whoſe Hand Writing is that?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I never could Write in my Life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon.
sp.p: Thoſe are the Names of ſuch as heard her ſay it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, you have Cooked it up bravely.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee what a brave Managery you have made of this poor Child. Read the Information.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Reads.— The Eighth of Auguſt, 1683. Jean Lodeman Aged about 13 Years, did in the preſence of theſe whoſe Names are Ʋnder-Written, declare as follows, That the ſaid Jean Lodeman was in the Tower on Friday Morning, the 13th of July laſt, and ſtanding almoſt over againſt the late Earl of Eſſex's Lodging Window, ſhe ſaw a Hand caſt out a Razour out of my Lords Window, and immediately upon that ſhe heard ſhrieks, and that there was a Souldier by my Lords door which cryed out to thoſe within the Houſe, that ſome body ſhould come and take up a Razour which was thrown out of the Window, whereupon there came a Maid with a White Hood of the Houſe, but who took up the Razour ſhe cannot tell.—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Here 'tis ſaid the Souldier cryed out, but now ſhe ſays, the Souldier ſhe does not know was there, and ſhe heard no body ſpeak to the Maid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon.
sp.p: With Submiſſion my Lord, I deſire to ask her this queſtion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Prithee ask her what thou wilt. We hear what ſhe ſays.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon.
sp.p: Did you hear the Souldier cry out, or did you not?

sp.speaker: Lode.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon.
sp.p: Did not you ſay, you heard him cry out?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we cannot admit Mr. Braddon ſhould ask ſuch Queſtions, they are leading Queſtions. Ask her a general Queſtion, and you ſhall have an Anſwer, but you ſhall not give her words to Swear to.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, Upon my word, you have given her too many words to Swear to already.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon.
sp.p: My Lord, I only writ what ſhe declared.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Were you carried by Mr. Braddon before any Magiſtrate, or any Juſtice of Peace.

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did he take the Examination himſelf?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Did not he deſire you to go before a Juſtice of Peace to be Sworn?

sp.speaker: Lodeman.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did he Write it himſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Ay, he Writ it and took it, and this Woman that is coming here, is a Witneſs to it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is this Womans Name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon.
sp.p: This is the Aunt Margaret Smith.

div.p: (Who was Sworn.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well what ſay you to her?

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon.
sp.p: I deſire to know, what this Girl ſaid to you, when ſhe returned from the Tower the 13th of July?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smith.
sp.p: She ſaid to that effect that ſhe ſpeaks now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon.
sp.p: What was that? tell the Court.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smith,
sp.p: I chid her becauſe ſhe had been playing: That is all I can ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Withins,
sp.p: Did ſhe tell you, the Soldier cried out for ſome body to come and take up the Razor?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smith,
sp.p: I cannot ſay that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Withins,
sp.p: Did ſhe ſay, ſhe ſaw a Razor thrown out of my Lord of Eſſex's Window?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smith,
sp.p: She ſaid, ſhe ſaw a Razor thrown out of a Window; I can't tell whether ſhe ſaid out of my Lord of Eſſex's Window.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke,
sp.p: Did you ſet your hand to that Paper?

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: Were you a Witneſs to that Paper?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smith,
sp.p: There were others heard what the Girl ſaid, as well as I.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: Who deſired you to ſign it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke,
sp.p: Who writ that Paper, Mrs.?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smith
sp.p: Pray excuſe me, Sir, I do not know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke,
sp.p: Did you ſee it writ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smith,
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: No: it was one got ready drawn by Mr. Braddon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Holloway,
sp.p: Pray let the Boy's Information be read again; for I obſerve there is a difference; ſhe ſays, the Razor fell within the Pales, the Boy ſays, it fell without.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the one ſays it was the inſide, the other the outſide of the Pales.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: Go on now, and ask your Queſtions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: Did the Girl ſay, That after the Razor was thrown out, the Soldier cried to ſome body to take it up?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smith,
sp.p: Sir, I can ſay no more than what I have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: Did ſhe, or did ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smith,
sp.p: Pray, Sir, excuſe me; I have ſpoken what I know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You may ſee how he has managed this matter, my Lord, by his urging the Witneſſes with Queſtions they know nothing of.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we ſee he would fain put words into their mouths.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mrs. Did you ſend to Mr. Braddon to inform him of what the Girl had ſaid? or did he come to you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smith,
sp.p: Sir, I never ſaw him before in my days.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: He came firſt to you then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smith,
sp.p: Yes: he hearing of it, came as a ſtranger to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: Did I, directly or indirectly, offer you, or your Neece, any thing?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Smith,
sp.p: No, never in this World.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: Did I ever deſire her, or you, to ſay any thing but what was true?

sp.speaker: Mrs.. Smith,
sp.p: No, Sir: You ever encouraged the Girl to ſpeak truth; and bid her ſpeak nothing but what was truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You need not pay dear for a Lie; you are like to pay dear enough before you have done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: My Lord, As to perſonal knowledg, I am as much a ſtranger to this matter as any body here; and in all my Concern in it, I have done nothing but what was very fair.

sp.speaker: L. C. Just.
sp.p: Mind your Defence, Mr. Braddon, and leave commending your ſelf; or if you will, rather commend your ſelf by your Actions than your Expreſſions: One good Action is worth Twenty good Expreſſions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: Swear William Glasbrook (which was done).

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, what do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke,
sp.p: My Lord, We deſire to know of him, whether he was by on the 13th of July, when the Girl gave this Report?

sp.speaker: Mr. Glasbrooke,
sp.p: I was up two pair of ſtairs when ſhe came in.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: What is your Name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Ay, here is his Information, among thoſe that were taken about Braddon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Glasbrooke,
sp.p: She came in to her Aunt, that went out juſt now before me, and I heard her very loud with her Aunt, ſaying, the Earl of Eſſex had cut his Throat in the Tower. Her Aunt chid her upon it; and her Aunt chiding her, ſhe ſaid, ſhe was ſure it was true; for ſhe ſaw a bloody Razor, with a bloody hand, thrown out of the Window.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke,
sp.p: Was this the day of my Lord of Eſſex's Death?

sp.speaker: Mr. Glasbrooke,
sp.p: It was the day the King was in the Tower, and, as was reported, the day he was killed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: Were you preſent when I firſt diſcourſed the Girl?

sp.speaker: Mr. Glasbrooke,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: Had you ever ſeen me before, or no?

sp.speaker: Mr. Glasbrooke,
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: Did ſhe ſay, my Lord of Eſſex cut his Throat at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Glasbrooke,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: Are you a Witneſs to this Paper? Did you ſet your hand to this Paper?

sp.speaker: Mr. Glasbrooke,
sp.p: To the Paper Mr. Braddon writ, I did: I am a Witneſs to that.

sp.speaker: L. C. Just.
sp.p: Then read his Information.

sp.speaker: Cl. of Cr.
sp.p: Reads, —Mr. William Glasbrooke does declare, That one Jean Lodeman, aged about Thirteen years, inhabiting in the ſame houſe where he, the ſaid William Glasbrooke, lodged, did on Friday, the 13th of July laſt past, between Ten and Eleven in the morning, in the preſence and hearing of him, the ſaid William Glasbrooke, declare to her Aunt, That the Earl of Eſſex had cut his throat; upon which her Aunt was very angry with her; whereupon ſhe, the ſaid girl, did declare, That ſhe was ſure of it; for ſhe ſaw him throw the Razor out of the Window; and that the Razor was bloody; and that ſhe heard two groans or ſhreeks (which of the two words ſhe uſed, he, the ſaid William Glasbrooke, is not certain): Of this he, the ſaid William Glasbrooke, is ready to make Oath.

sp.speaker: L. C. Just.
sp.p: Now my Lord of Eſſex cut his own Throat, and after threw the Razor out of the Window.

sp.speaker: Mr. Glasbrooke,
sp.p: 'Tis what the Girl did declare.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Does not this Girl uſually tell Lies?

sp.speaker: Mr. Glasbrooke,
sp.p: I have before that time taken her in a Lie.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you acquaint Mr. Braddon with that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Glasbrooke,
sp.p: I cannot tell that I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember that you told Mr. Braddon, That ſhe was a Girl that told Truth?

sp.speaker: Mr. Glasbrooke,
sp.p: No, I never did that; for I was always of another perſwaſion about her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: He never was of that Temper, to praiſe her; he was always of a contrary perſwaſion.

sp.speaker: L C. Just.
sp.p: I'le aſſure him, that I am of his Opinion too: I do believe ſhe is a lying Girl, and hath told us a company of Lies now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: Theſe Two Children told me, they never ſaw one another till they were examined at Council.

sp.speaker: L. C. Just.
sp.p: Well, well: go on with your Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p:
Where is William Smith (who appeared, and was ſworn)? I deſire
to know of you, Mr. Smith, what you heard the Girl ſay, when I was there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: I heard the Girl tell us, That ſhe ſaw a hand caſt out a Razor, and either the hand was bloody, or the Razor, I can't tell which; but ſhe ſaid it was out of the Window, where ſhe ſaid the Earl of Eſſex lodged.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did ſhe ſay the Earl of Eſſex did it himſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: She ſaid, ſhe ſaw an Hand caſt out a Razor.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did ſhe tell you, it was the Earl of Eſſex's Lodging-Window?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: She ſaid it was that Lodging.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, but ſhe ſays now, ſhe does not know it to be his Lodging.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: My Lord, ſhe ſays ſhe was told it was his Lodging.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you have made her to ſay poſitively, it was his Lodging, and that he threw out the Razor.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir, where did you firſt hear this Report of this Girl?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: There at the houſe, where ſhe was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Were you alone, when you went to the Girl the firſt time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: No, I went with Mr. Braddon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing of it before? What did induce you to go along with Mr. Braddon? What were the Arguments that prevail'd with you to go with him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: I did not know where he was going; Mr. Braddon called me at the Shop, as I ſtood at the Door, and ask'd me if I was buſie, or would go with him? ſo I went with him to the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You never heard one word before of the Girl's report?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What elſe did the Girl tell you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: I can't ſay what elſe ſhe ſaid. This I remember that I have told you.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did ſhe name the Earl of Eſſex's Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: I am ſure ſhe ſaid, the Lodging where the Earl of Eſſex lay.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did ſhe name the Earl of Eſſex?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: She did name the Earl of Eſſex's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did ſhe in ſo many words ſay, That it was the Earl of Eſſex's Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip ſees they give one Evidence, and ſhe another.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: I cannot ſay, whether ſhe did in ſo many words ſay ſo, or no; but ſhe ſaid, That ſhe ſaw a Hand toſs out a Razor, and either the hand was bloody, or the Razor, and it was where my Lord of Eſſex's Lodgings was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But did ſhe name my Lord of Eſſex's Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: Yes, ſhe did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what elſe did ſhe ſay? Tell us all ſhe ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: She ſaid, there was a man ſtood below, and ſhe heard two ſhrieks, and the Man did ſay, Here is a Razor; and a Woman came out, or one in Womans cloths, with white headcloths. Mr. Braddon asked if ſhe ſee any Body take it up, and ſhe ſaid, no; but ſhe heard a Man ſay, here is the Razor, and ſhe ſaw a Woman come out.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You are ſure that is all you heard her ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: I think ſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Recollect your ſelf, pray good Mr. Smith.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: I do not know, that I heard any thing elſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray read his Information.

sp.speaker: C. of C.
sp.p: Here is William Smith ſubſcribed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: Mr. Braddon writ down what the Girl ſaid, and we did read it over all, and then ſet our hands to it.

sp.speaker: L. C J.
sp.p: Well, Sir, Read the Information then.

sp.speaker: C. of C.
sp.p: Reads the Information as before —

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You hear what you have affirmed in this Paper that the Girl ſaid; you have forgot in your Evidence now, this long buſineſs about the Soldier.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: My Lord, I have told all I did remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, you have ſet your Hand to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: I did read it over, and it was nothing but what the Girl ſaid, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where do you live?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: In Throgmorton-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Trade?

sp.speaker: Mr. Smith,
sp.p: A Barber.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: A notable Shaver upon my Word! a ſpecial fellow I'le warrant him!

sp.speaker: Mr· Braddon,
sp.p: Call Mrs. Mewx (who appeared and was Sworn.) Pray what day was it, you went from London to Barkſhire?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mewx,
sp.p: The day before my Lord Ruſſel was tryed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: What Expreſſion did you hear from a Gentleman in the Coach?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: We muſt not ſuffer ſuch a Queſtion to be asked, that is not Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: My Lord, I ask the Queſtion in general terms, what ſhe heard ſuch a day?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Does ſhe know any thing of her own Knowledg?

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: She can tell what ſhe heard, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis no Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: Will your Lordſhip pleaſe to hear what ſhe ſays.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, I will not hear what I ſhould not hear; let her ſpeak what ſhe knows.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: She knows this, that a Woman told her—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask your Councel, whether that be Evidence. If you will not be ſatisfied with what I ſay, ask them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop,
sp.p: She proves a Report.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I ask it of you, Mr. Wallop, Is what another ſaid to her, Evidence in this Caſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop,
sp.p: My Lord, If really there was ſuch a Report—

sp.speaker: L C. J.
sp.p: Is that Evidence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop,
sp.p: 'Tis Evidence there were ſuch a Talk, and that is Evidence of the probability of the thing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I'le leave it to your ſelf, If you as a Lawyer ſay 'tis Evidence, we will hear it, becauſe you ſay ſo; but I believe you nor no body elſe will offer to ſay any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop,
sp.p: My Lord, we lay it before the Court as part of the Ground upon which we went in our being concerned in this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J:
sp.p: Is that a Juſtification of Mr. Braddon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop,
sp.p: Upon theſe probabilities he ingaged in this matter, and to prove this Report he brings this Gentlewoman to tell what ſhe heard.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, is what the VVoman told her, Evidence? She reported a Report to me, can that be Evidence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop,
sp.p: My Lord, with ſubmiſſion, we think it juſtifies Mr. Braddon, that he went upon theſe grounds.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is the Woman that told her? why is not ſhe brought?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop,
sp.p: They ſay, She is ſo big with Child, ſhe can't come.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, if that Woman were here her ſelf, if ſhe did ſay it, and would not Swear it, we could not hear her; how then can her ſaying, be Evidence before us? I wonder to hear any man that wears a Gown, to make a doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: I deſire Jeremy Burgis may be called, (who appeared and was Sworn.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop,
sp.p: VVhat can you ſay about the Report in the Country?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: I was at Frome about my buſineſs on a Fryday —

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
VVhy Gent. what are we doing all this time? Do you think we
ſit here for nothing? Is not this the firſt time that a Report was given as Evidence in Weſtminſter-Hall?

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke,
sp.p: My Lord, We are neceſſitated to uſe this ſort of Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. C. Just.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, It is no evidence, be neceſſitated what you will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Freke,
sp.p: My Lord, They have produced this man's Letter that was taken about Mr. Braddon, that is produced in Evidence againſt him: now this man comes to give an Account how he came to write that Letter.

sp.speaker: L. C. Just.
sp.p: But he ſhall not give an Account by a Report in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: It was written to the Landlord of the houſe where I quartered, that he might give notice to Mr. Braddon of a Diſcourſe that paſſed in his houſe that Friday, of a Report that was there concerning the Earl of Eſſex's murdering himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Had the Maſter of the houſe told you any ſuch thing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: No, he had not told me ſo; but I heard it in the houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. Just.
sp.p: Of whom did you hear it? who told you ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Sir, I was a ſtranger there.

sp.speaker: L. C. Just.
sp.p: They can never tell, any of them, who it was firſt reported it, nor particularly who told it them; but it was reported by ſome body, we don't know who.

sp.speaker: Mr. Beech,
sp.p: Under favour, my Lord, I rode directly to the Post-Master at Froome, whither this Letter was directed; and by the way, there is a Remark in the Letter of an alteration of the Figure, 'tis interlined the 13th: it was not ſo before▪ to hit the day exactly of the murder of the Earl of Eſſex; and when I came thither, the Post Master told me, There was no ſuch Report in his houſe, nor in the whole Town at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I deſire to know, upon your Oath, who told you that Report?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beech,
sp.p: Sir, I do not know; I was a ſtranger there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was it a man or a woman?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: He did not tell his diſcourſe to me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But thou could'ſt gueſs by the Habit, whether it was a man or woman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: It was a man.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who did he tell it to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: The Company in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray let him tell how Mr. Braddon came to ſpeak to him about it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Shew him that Letter. Look upon it, friend: is that your hand?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Yes, it is.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you put that figure of 13. in? There was another figure before, and that is blotted out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: It was a miſtake in me: I miſtook the day, and I corrected it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you correct it? How ſoon did you correct it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Preſently.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhat day had you put in firſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: The 6th day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, but that was not the right day, man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: It was a great while after, and I did not expect to be brought in queſtion for any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long after?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Six weeks.

sp.speaker: L. C J.
sp.p: How cameſt thou to recollect, to make it from the 6th to the 13th, Six weeks after?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Mr. Braddon was there when I had writ it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And he corrected it; did he?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: He ſaid, That that was not the day of my Lord's Death.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You had written it the 6th, and he put you in mind of the 13th.

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And he was to be the meſſenger that carried the Letter himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: That is very well. I ſuppoſe Gent. you hear what he ſays, He ſays, Mr. Braddon was there and told him, that was not the day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Braddon ſaid, You have miſtaken the time, that will not do it, it muſt be the 13th.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray let me know one thing, Who recommended Braddon to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Indeed I can't tell.

sp.speaker: L C. J.
sp.p: Who did he ſay he came to you from? Tell the truth upon your Oath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Sir, I was at work at my buſineſs, and knew nothing of his coming.

sp.speaker: L C. J.
sp.p: What Trade art thou?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: A Pinmaker.

sp.speaker: L. C J.
sp.p: Where do you live?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: At Marlbrough.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came Mr. Braddon and you acquainted?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Sir, I will tell you: I was at work at my Trade, and there came down a Gent. that lives in our Town to me, and asked me—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is that Gentleman's name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Mr. Butcher.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is that Butcher.

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: A Gentleman that lives in Marlbrough, a Grazier by Trade. He came and told me, There was a Gentleman come from London, about the buſineſs now in diſpute——

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Prethee, what was ſpoke of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: It was concerning the Earl of Eſſex's Death. And he deſired me to ſpeak what I heard at ſuch a time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who had you told what you heard firſt, to? You muſt have told it to ſome Body; who did you tell it to firſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Indeed I can't directly ſay, who I did tell it to.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Had you told that Gentleman of your Town, Butcher, as you call him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: No, not that I know of.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, when he came to you, what then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: He deſired me to go to Mr. Braddon, to the White Hart. And ſo I went up to the White Hart; and when I came to Mr. Braddon, I told him what I had heard at Forme.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Then Mr. Braddon asked me the ſame Night, Whether I would go down along with him to Frome: and I could not; ſo then he deſired me to write a Letter to recommend him to the houſe where I had heard it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: And you did write that Letter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Yes, I did ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip obſerves, this Houſe was the Poſt-houſe, to be ſure, to have it ſpread in publick places.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you tell Butcher of your knowledg, before he carried you to Braddon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: VVhen?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Then, at that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did he ask you of your Knowledg, or did you tell him voluntarily?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: He asked me if I remembred any ſuch thing as I had ſpoken?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Why, had you ſpoke of it before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Yes, I had.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did he tell you upon whoſe recommendation he came to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: I do not know upon whoſe recommendation he came.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When you writ this Letter, did he dictate it to you, or did you write it of your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: I writ it of my ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he tell you what you ſhould write?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: I ſhewed him what I had written?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And when you writ it of your ſelf, you put in the 6th day?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Yes, I did ſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did he ſay then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Mr. Braddon ſaid, it was the 13th day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Why did you ſhew Braddon your Letter after you had written it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: He came to my houſe before I had ſealed it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But why did you ſhew him the Letter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: He deſired a Letter to recommend him to that man at whoſe houſe I heard it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What was he to be recommended to him for?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: It was to deſire him to enquire, who brought the News firſt to Town.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: You ſay, He deſired a Letter of Recommendation?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Yes; it was to recommend him to that man

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: That you may not be in a miſtake, pray recollect your ſelf; for there is not one word of Recommendation in the Letter. Tell the true Reaſon, why you ſhewed him the Letter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: I can't tell any other, but only he came before I had ſealed it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did he deſire to ſee it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: No: but the Letter lay writ upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was the Maſter of the Poſt-houſe at Frome, preſent when that Report you talk of, was made?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: I cannot rightly ſay whether he was or no.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How comeſt thou to put it in thus? This bears date a pretty while ago, Marlbrough, Aug. 21. and that was a good diſtance of time from that Report that thou talkeſt of: How comes thou then to ſay, Theſe are to deſire you to call to mind, That I was at Froom ſuch a time, and heard ſuch a Report: If he was not there, why ſhould he call to mind? VVhat did'ſt thou mean by that calling to mind?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: I would have had him called to mind my being at his houſe at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But if he was not there, why did'ſt thou ask him to call to mind that Report?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: He might hear of it from ſome other at that time, tho he might not hear it in that Company where I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: There is a Riddle in it, if we could but ſolve it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no. Mr. Solicitor, the Riddle is unfolded; 'tis a plain Contrivance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, from whom did he tell you he was recommended?

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: How came you to talk ſo to a ſtranger, Sir, whom you never ſee before, about ſuch a buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: He was recommended to me by Mr. Butcher, as I told you, who carried me to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But who, as Braddon, or Butcher told you, did recommend him firſt to come down thither to you?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Upon your Oath, Sir, who did Butcher tell you he came from?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: I have forgotten, Sir; I do not remember.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: VVas it not a Nonconformiſt Parſon, Sir, upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: Sir, I cannot remember.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Beech, Do you know any particular perſon that Braddon ſaid he came recommended from?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beech,
sp.p: I can tell what Account Braddon gave of his Journey himſelf: He ſaid, he had a Letter that came particularly from this man to London, to bring him down into the Weſt: Said I, When came you out of London? I came on Thurſday, ſaid he: Where did you lodg a Thurſday Night? At Ockingham? Said I, That is not your way to Marlbrough: Where did you lye the next night? He told me, at one Venables; and the next Night at Salisbury, I think.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did Braddon tell you, he had a Letter from that man?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beech,
sp.p: He ſaid, A Letter from that man brought him down into the Weſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Burgis, Did you ſend him e're a Letter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: No: I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Beech,
sp.p: He ſaid, he came down purpoſely upon this Report.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What ſaid the Poſt-Maſter to you, Mr. Beech?

sp.speaker: Mr. Beech,
sp.p: If you pleaſe to give me leave to ſpeak, I'le tell you: I did deſire, that Mr. Braddon might have no Pen and Ink, and preſently I rid away to Froom, to this Poſt-Maſter's houſe, and ſpake with the Poſt-Maſter, and all his Family: We then examined them all, and there was no ſuch Report in that Town till the Sunday after.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol Gen.
sp.p: He was perſwaded, ſure, all people would ſay juſt as he would have them.

sp.speaker: Mr Thompſon,
sp.p: Well, Mr. Braddon, Who do you call next?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Nay, I deſire this man may go on; for methinks he mends e're a ſtep he goes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: Mr. Burgis, Do you remember how it was that you came to recollect your ſelf, and to know it was the 13th, and not the 6th?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays, You told him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: Pray, Sir, remember your ſelf, whether you did not ſay your ſelf, You remembred the true time; for you came from Froom to Marlbrough on the Saturday night, and then you heard there the Earl of Eſſex had cut his Throat the day before; and when they told you ſo, you cried out How can that be? It muſt be done before; for yeſterday I heard it at Froom before Five of the Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Withins,
sp.p: Did not Mr. Braddon himſelf tell you, You had miſtaken the day?

sp.speaker: Mr. Brad.
sp.p: Sir, It was from this, He told this whole Story that I juſt now repeated, that the Saturday night he was told, That the Earl had cut his Throat, and replyed to them, that he had heard at Frome, the day before that he was murdered, and then I ſaid, that muſt be the 13.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came you to tell that man, You had a Letter from Burgis?

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: No, My Lord, I did not tell him any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: L. C J.
sp.p: Mr. Beech, Did not he tell you he had a Letter from Burgis?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burgis,
sp.p: He told me he came down upon the Information of this Burgis.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And he Swears he never ſaw him before nor never writ to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Brad.
sp.p: You ask me, whether I had received any Letter from this Burgis, I told you I had a Letter of Recommendation to Mr. Butcher, thinking he had been the Perſon that had reported it, and Mr. Butcher went to this Perſon and brought him to me, and he told me what he heard:

sp.speaker: Mr. Beech,
sp.p: I never heard of the name of Butcher, till now he mentioned it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Braddon,
sp.p: My Lord, I will call no more Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip and the Jury obſerve, I ſuppoſe, his confident Behaviour.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, He is no more concerned at it, than if he had been doing the moſt juſtifiable thing in the World.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompſon,
sp.p: My Lord, I have but one word to add on the behalf of Mr. Speke, who is likewiſe joyned in this Information. Truly, Mr. Speke is a young Gentleman of ſome quality, his Father is of very good Quality, Mr. Braddon was of his Acquaintance, and being his Acquaintance, and thus concerned, as you have heard in the Proſecution of this buſineſs; he hearing of theſe Reports, and reſolving to go down into the Country about it, deſired Mr. Speke to lend him his Man and his Saddle, for he was going into the Country. Mr. Speke inquires what his buſineſs was, thereupon he told him it was to inquire about ſome Perſons that had reported ſomething relating to the Earl of Eſſex's Death. And being to go into the Country where Mr. Speke, who was that Country man, had ſome Acquaintance, upon this he deſires him to write him a Letter to recommend him to ſome Perſons of Credit. He did write that Letter, but was never concerned in this buſineſs, either before or after; and this is the whole of the Caſe, as to this Mr. Speke.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke,
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire▪ I may ſpeak one word for my ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, ſay what you will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke,
sp.p: My Lord, One day, ſometime after Mr. Braddon had concerned himſelf in this thing, I met him caſually and accidentally, and he was telling me ſomewhat of the matter. And after this, one night as I was going to Bed between 10 and 11 a Clock at night, ſome Body knocked hard at my Door. My man went to the door, and opened the door, and Mr. Braddon comes in and tells me, he deſired the favour of me, that I would lend him my man, and lend him my Saddle. He being my Acquaintance, and I knowing him, I was willing to do him that kindneſs; and asking him, whither he went? He told me he was going down to Marlbrough, and he told me he had heard that my Lord of Eſſex's Death was diſcourſed of there in the Country, that day it was done; beſides other things of a Boy, and of a Girl, that could prove ſuch and ſuch things. Said I, this is a thing of great concernment, and I would have you take good advice in it, before you proceed, becauſe otherwiſe it may be a Reflection upon the Government; therefore, ſaid I, I would not have you proceed to concern your ſelf further in this thing, but take the Advice and Judgment of ſome prudent and diſcreet Perſon or other, that you may do nothing but what is according to Law. I was never at all concerned, nor knew any thing of the buſineſs, but what I heard from Mr. Braddon at firſt. And before he came into my Chamber, I knew nothing of his coming; and I writ this Letter, becauſe he ſhould not concern himſelf without the Advice of ſome Perſon, that I thought was able to Adviſe him, that he might do nothing that might bring him within the danger of the Law, or reflect upon the Government.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Holloway,
sp.p: And you adviſed him to go by the name of Johnſon, not Braddon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke,
sp.p: It was late at Night, and I had been at the Tavern drinking a Bottle of Wine or two with a Friend, and might not ſo well conſider what I did write.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But Mr. Speke, You hear what you writ, We row againſt ſtream, and we thank you for the Countenance you have given to us. And here is a worthy Gentleman, Mr. Braddon, who is a very proper man for the deſign he has in hand, and none better than he, and when you are with him, you may diſcourſe freely, and he is true a man, and a ſtout man, and fit to be truſted; but he muſt not go by the name of Braddon, but of Johnſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke,
sp.p: My Lord, the Reaſon was, becauſe he was not perſonally know to Sir Robert Atkins; and for him to go down directly and to have it reported one of ſuch a name came to Sir Robert Atkins, who was a man that had retired himſelf into the Country from all publick concern, I thought not ſo well

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why did you trouble him, if he was ſo retired?

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke,
sp.p: I had particular Concerns of my own, that Sir Robert Atkins was pleaſed to concern himſelf for me, and I knew him a prudent man that would adviſe him nothing but according to Law.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſhould not have diſturbed him in his privicies, Mr. Speke.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke,
sp.p: My Lord, I never was any other way concerned, I knew nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You had done well if you had not concerned your ſelf about it at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Moſt here do fear, you ſay, that he will be either Stabbed or Knocked on the head, and therefore you lent him your man to guard him, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke,
sp.p: He deſired me to lend him my man, becauſe he did not know the way ſo well himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: But why was there ſuch fear about him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke,
sp.p: I know nothing at all of the matter, but what I had from Mr. Braddon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, we live in ſuch a ſtabbing Age, that ſuch an extraordinary Genteleman as Mr. Braddon, that is ſuch an extraordinary good Proteſtant, can't walk the ſtreets for fear of being murdered.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke,
sp.p: My Lord, I writ it at ſuch a time of the Night after I had been at the Tavern, that I knew not well what I writ.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Withins,
sp.p: Mr. Speke, You ſee what a ſort of man he is, upon the Evidence that hath been given.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke.
sp.p: Truly my Lord, I never knew any thing, but what I had from him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: But to make the Country believe, that there were ſuch endeavours here to ſtifle any thing that might give light into the Murder of the Earl of Eſſex, there muſt be great caution uſed to conceal his Name.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Yes, being ſuch a Vertuous Man, as Mr. Bradden, there was great need of all circumſpection and care to preſerve him, Why did not he get his Life-Guard to keep him from the danger, that was thought ſo near him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: They had not raiſed them as yet, but he was contented at preſent with Mr. Speke's Man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke.
sp.p: My Lord, I am wholly innocent in all this matter.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Would to God you were Innocent. You are a Man of Quality, Mr. Speke, I know; I ſhould be glad you were Innocent with all my heart▪ But when Men forget their Studies and their own Buſineſs, and take upon them the Politicks without being called to it, That puts them into Frenzies, and then they take all opportunities of ſhewing themſelves men of Zeal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We need but read the Letter which Mr. Speke has owned, and you will ſay it is ten times worſe than what Mr. Bradden has done.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Nay, I will not have Mr. Bradden topped upon for all that, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, if you read it once again, you will find that he therein owns it all, and pins the Basket upon himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Indeed, Mr. Attorney, I will not have ſuch a Reflection put upon Mr. Bradden, That any man ſhould be a greater Actor in the buſineſs, than he.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke.
sp.p: My Lord, I writ it at night after a Bottle of Wine, and other people may be miſtaken, as well as I.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: If ſome of theſe Gentlemen, that now and then think themſelves better headed than others, and that are ſo extraordinarily concerned to preſerve our Religion, but are generally much miſtaken, were, and I obſerve their miſtakes are always on the wrong ſide, I wiſh you could have gon and recollected your ſelf next Morning Mr. Speke, and then the miſtake had been more pardonable.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke.
sp.p: I writ nothing as to matter of Fact, but what he told me, and I could hardly recollect it next Morning, when he was gone away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Record.
sp.p: My Lord, We ſhall prove he has bragged, that is Mr. Bradden, That he was the only inventer of the Proteſtant Flailes, an Inſtrument you have heard of, Gentlemen, and for what uſe deſigned.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But, Brother Jenner; that is nothing to the purpoſe now, what he was before this buſineſs, or what he was after. You are, Gentlemen, to Try him upon this Indictment only, and are not to mind any other thing at all.

div.p: Then Mr. Speke's Letter was read again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You ſee, Gentlemen, in what Strain it runs, We and We, He makes himſelf a conſiderable Party in the Deſign.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Ay, We thank you for your kindneſs towards Ʋs, and We hope to bring on the Tryal of the Earl of Eſſex, before they can any of thoſe in the Tower.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke.
sp.p: He told me, Sir Henry Capel ſaid it was a thing too great for him to meddle with. And I knew nothing, but what I had from him.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: He was a man of Integrity, and could tell you nothing but what was true, Mr. Speke.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p:
My Lord, All I can ſay for Mr. Speke is this, He did believe Mr. Bradden's Grounds, as he told him, were probable to go upon, but he
knew nothing himſelf, and concerned himſelf no further. I hope the Jury will conſider of it, that there is no contrivance proved againſt him.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Wallop, tho' we interrupted you in making Remarks upon every Witneſs, yet now make what Remarks upon what hath been ſaid that you will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wallop.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſhall leave it to your Lordſhip and the Jury, how far they think the Defendant Guilty of this Information.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, We have indeed given as great an Evidence as ever was given I think of any Offence. But to clear up the matter, that it was impoſſible for any man, unleſs the moſt maliciouſly and villanouſly inclined againſt the Government and Peace of the Kingdom, that can be, to imagine ſuch a thing, much leſs ſpread ſuch a Report, we will call you two or three Witneſſes to prove, that the Earl of Eſſex Murdered himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: 'Tis neceſſary, Mr. Attorney, I think for you ſo to do, to ſatisfie the World, tho' to a diſcerning Eye there is enough given from the Evidence this day, to make it appear to be a moſt Malitious and Scandalous Contrivance, to hawke about for every idle Rumor, to pick up Children of ſuch tender years, and make them ſwear any thing to ſerve a turn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, We do not call theſe Witneſſes, as if there were any doubt of it in the World.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But we live in an Age, when Truth paſſes for nothing in the World, and Swearing and Forſwearing is taken for a thing of courſe. Had his Zeal been half ſo much for Truth as it was for Falſhood it had been a commendable Zeal. But when men are ſo zealous and fierce for ſuch vile things as theſe are, 'tis time of my word for the Government to interpoſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: 'Tis not to ſatisfie the Court nor the Jury, who I believe are all of them already ſufficiently ſatisfied, but 'tis to ſatisfie the World, that may have entertained ſome prejudices from this Conſpiracy. Call Mr. Bomeney in.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Not as if there were any doubt, whether Mr. Bradden were the malicious Inventor of this Report at the beginning, and went down into the Country to ſpread it. The Evidence has been full, and by his own management of his Defence, he has proved it himſelf, and ſeems by his Confidence to juſtifie it. But we ſhall, to give the World ſome ſatisfaction, call ſome that waited upon the Earl in the Tower, and others that ſaw him when dead, that will give a plain Confutation to any thing that could be ſuppoſed, as if my Lord of Eſſex had not Murdered himſelf.

div.p: Then Bomeney was ſworn.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you waite upon this unfortunate Gentleman, my Lord of Eſſex?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, what do you know of his Death?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: I went with him from White-Hall, and I ſtayed with him all the while he was in the Tower.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How came he by that unhappy End, pray?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p:
When we were at his Lodging, my Lord uſed to call for a Pen-knife to cut his Nails of his Hands and Feet, and he then had long Nails, and ſaid he to me, give me your Pen-knife to cut my Nails; ſaid I, My Lord, I have none, I came in haſte, but I will ſend to morrow for one; and therefore I ſent our Footman, one William Turner; to whom I gave a little Note for Proviſions, and among other things which I writ directions to the Steward to ſend, there was a little line; Pray ſend a Pen-knife for my Lord. He brought ſome Proviſions, but he did not bring a Pen-knife on the Thurſday, becauſe he ſaid he had none, but he would ſend one the
morrow after; I ſent William Turner the Morning after very early, and gave him another little Note for Proviſions; and, among other things, I writ in the Note, Do not forget the Pen-knife for my Lord. He went, and when he was in the way, my Lord ſent the Warder to me to call me. I came to my Lord, and my Lord asked, Is the Footman come? Has he brought the Pen-knife? No, my Lord, ſaid I, but I hope he will not ſtay long, becauſe I ſent him early. Then I was turning to come down from the Chamber, and I ſaw my Lord walking in the Room and picking of his Nails with the Pen-knife.—

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How? with a Pen-knife?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: No, with the Razour that I gave him. For I went to my Lord, and when my Lord asked me, if I had gotten him a Pen-knife. I ſaid, the Footman was not come, but I hoped it would come immediately, becauſe I ſent him early. And I was turning from the Chamber, thinking I had done with my Lord, and my Lord called me again, Harke you, Bomeney, ſaid he, I can do it with one of your Razours. My Lord, ſaid I, I will fetch one, ſo I went into my Cloſet and fetched one. And I went to my Lord, and when he had it, he did as if he picked his Nails with it, and was walking in the Chamber. I looked a little while upon him, and turned out of the Chamber into the Paſſage, where I talked with the Warder, Ruſſel his Name was, and when I looked out of the Window, His Majeſty was in the Tower, and there was a great buſtle in the Street; and when I had talked a little with the Warder, I went down into my Cloſet again, and at the ſame time that I was in my Cloſet, there came the Footman, and one with him, that brought the Proviſions, and he gave me the Pen-knife, and gave me a little Note, that he had brought with the Proviſions, which, he ſaid, Mr. Billingsly, that was our Steward, bid me to ſhew that to my Lord. I took it, and went up to ſhew it to my Lord; I found no body in my Lords Chamber, There was a Cloſet there, in which was a Cloſe Stool; and that I found ſhut, and thinking my Lord was there, I would not diſturb my Lord, but came down again and ſtayed a little while, in ſo much as I thought my Lord by that time might have been come out. I went up again and found no body in the Chamber, but the Cloſet Door ſhut ſtill, I went againſt the Door, and knocked three times and ſaid, My Lord, My Lord, and no body anſwered: Then I looked through the chink of the Door, between the Door and the Wall, and I could ſee blood, and a little part of the Razour. Then I called to the Warder and the People of the Houſe, and they came up and found him there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Had you much adoe to open the Door, or could you open the Door eaſily?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: No, the Door could not be opened eaſily, I know not how they opened the Door, but I think Ruſſel the Warder, when he came up, puſhed at the Door, but could not open it very far, becauſe my Lords Foot was againſt the Door, and ſo they had much adoe to open the Door.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Which way does the Door open out of the Room, or into the Room?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: Inward, into the Room.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: And ſo, his Feet being againſt it, it could not eaſily be opened.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How big is the Cloſet?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: A very little Cloſet, I believe, no wider than that; and the length of a Man, and a Cloſe Stool at the upper end would fill it up My Lord lay all along on his ſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you obſerve your Lord melancholly, Mr. Bomeney?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: Yes, he was melancholly. But we took no notice of it, for he was uſed to be ſo, and we had no reaſon to ſuſpect any thing more than ordinary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you find the Razour?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: Yes, it lay by him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What became of the Razour?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: The Coroners Jury had it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was there any Window in that Room, where the Cloſe Stool was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: Yes, there was a Window.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was there a Caſement to that Window?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: Yes, I think there might.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Withens.
sp.p: Which way does that Window look?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: I can't very well remember, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Withens.
sp.p: Which way do you think?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: I believe it is upon a yard.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: He ſays, he does not well know. But, Mr. Bomeney, you ſaw Mr. Ruſſel the Warder in the ſame place, as you came up again, that you left him in when you went down?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: My Lord, I went down but a little while.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Where did you find Ruſſel the Warder, when you came up again?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: At the Guard.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you find him in the ſame poſture, when you went up again, that you left him when you went down?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you hear of any body that went up elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then we will call Mr. Ruſſel the Warder he ſpeaks of. (Who was ſworn.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, will you give my Lord an account at that time where you were, and what was done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: I was in the Chamber next oppoſite againſt my Lords Chamber, there is but a little ſtep betwixt the Doors, the Stairs come up betwixt the two Doors, no body could paſs backwards or forwards, but I muſt ſee them; for I was then Waiter at that time, and ſtood upon the Guard; and my Lord asked Mr. Bomeney, Whether the Pen-knife was come; and he told my Lord, No. Then, ſays he, lend me your Razour, that will do it. And my Lord took the Razour in his Hand, and the Door was open, and he went two or three turns in the Room with the Razour ſo. This I ſaw, the Door being open, as I ſtood in the Paſſage. My Lord, by and by Mr. Bomeney goes down, and my Lord ſhut the Door to him, and Mr. Bomeney ſtaid below a little while, and afterwards comes up again. And my Lord was gone to the Cloſet to Stool as he ſuppoſed. So away he comes down again, and ſtaid about a quarter of an hour or there abouts. And this I ſee all my ſelf, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Had any Perſon been there from the time Bomeney went down to the time he came up again?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: No, my Lord, there was no body went up or down all the time, but Bomeney. He came up, and ſeeing my Lord was not come out of his Cloſet, (this I did ſtand and hear) ſo he puts by the Hanging, and looks in, and ſees my Lord in his Blood lying in the Cloſet; and he makes an Oration, a great noiſe, with that I ſtepped two or three ſteps, hearing him make ſuch an Oration, and I found the Key was on the out-ſide of the Door, and I opened the Door, and ſaw him lye in his Blood.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Could you open the Door with eaſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: Yes, I could put it a little way open, and there ſaw him.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But you could not put it quite open?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: No, for his Legs lay againſt the Door.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was it a narrow Cloſet?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: Yes, a very narrow Cloſet.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: In what poſture did my Lord lye?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: He lay all along on one ſide.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Where lay the Razour?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: By him. But I did not take ſo much notice of the Razour, for I was ſurprized with the ſight.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Holloway.
sp.p: Was there any Window in the Cloſet?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: Yes, that looks into Captain Hawley's yard. And the Window is quite Northward.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Which way does that Window look?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: Quite the other way, into the Back-yard.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Then there is no Way out, nor Light, nor Caſement out into the Fore-yard.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: No, my Lord, 'tis backward, and 'tis Paled in, only into the Houſe there is a Door.

sp.speaker: M. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was there any Door out of the Street, that way?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: No, there is one Door that goes out from the Entry to go into the Yard.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Has any body elſe acceſs to come to the Yard, but what muſt come thro' Hawley's Houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: No, no body.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: We will call Captain Hawley himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Warder, Do you remember there was any Coach that ſtood there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ruſſel.
sp.p: No, there was no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: I ask you for this reaſon, becauſe here was a Girl that ſpake of a Coach, that came thro' the Houſe I ſuppoſe, and ſo thro' the Entry out of that Door into the Yard.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where is Lloyd the Souldier? For, my Lord, as there was a Warder above, ſo there was a Souldier that ſtood at the Door below. And while he ſtayed there, there could not any one come in, nor near, but he muſt obſerve them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, be pleaſed to ask Mr. Bomeney, how long he lived with my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How long had you lived with my Lord of Eſſex?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: Six years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wythens.
sp.p: You waited on him in his Chamber I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bomeney.
sp.p: Yes, in the Nature of his Valet de Chambre.

div.p: Then Lloyd was ſworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Hark you Lloyd, you were the Sentinel. Give an account where you ſtood that day, that my Lord of Eſſex Murdered himſelf?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: At my Lords Door.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Which Door?

sp.speaker: Loyd.
sp.p: At my Lord of Eſſex's Door.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Were you above Stairs, or below at the Street Door?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: Below at the Street Door.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wythens.
sp.p: Did any body come into the Houſe that morning?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: No body came in, all the while I ſtood there, that I knew of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wythens.
sp.p: Were you there at that time, when my Lord killed himſelf?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: I was there, when the noiſe was made of it above Stairs.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſee e're a Coach there?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: Not to ſtand at the Door at all.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Didſt thou ſee e're a Coach in Captain Hawley's Back-yard?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why, could not the Coach go thro' the Door and the Entry into the Yard?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Had you ſeen my Lord of Eſſex that morning?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: Yes, he ſpake to me, and asked me, What a Clock it was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Where was he?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: At the Caſement.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What did he ſay to you?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: He ſaid Centry, What a Clock is it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee him, when my Lord Ruſſel went by?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw him then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long after was the Cry of my Lords having killed himſelf?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: I believe, not half an hour after.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did any Maid go out of the Houſe?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: None at all.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What, not in a White Hood?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why, did'ſt not thou call to the Maid to come and take up the Razour, that was thrown out of the Window of Captain Hawley's Houſe?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: There was no Razour at all thrown out, that I ſaw?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did not you open the Pales for her to go in, and take up the Razour?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was there any other Souldier there beſides you?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Then, you muſt be he that cryed out, or no body?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: I ſaw no Razour, nor did not cry out to any body.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Could you open the Pales? Is there a Door to the Street-ſide out of the Pales into the Yard?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: 'Tis no Yard, but there is a Door that all paſs thro' that come to the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What elſe did my Lord of Eſſex ſay to you?

sp.speaker: Lloyd.
sp.p: He only examined me, what a Clock it was? that was all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, We have here two Women, who were the only Women that were in the Houſe, they will tell you, what they ſaw.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Pray, Gentlemen, do not miſpend your time unneceſſarily, becauſe I am to ſit this afternoon at London.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, We will then only call Captain Hawley, (who was ſworn.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Captain, tell what you know of this matter?

sp.speaker: Capt. Hawley.
sp.p: My Lord; All the account I can give, is, That about 4 or 5 a Clock in the Morning, I went to open the Gates, that being the uſual hour to open the Gates. And I was at the Gate then when a Warder came, and told me, my Lord of Eſſex had killed himſelf, and that was between 9 and 10 of the Clock. When I came into the Houſe, I went up Stairs, and ſaw no body in the Room, nor no Blood; ſaid I, to the Warder, What do you make a Fool of me? here is nothing: Says one of the Warders, look into the Cloſet, I went to the Cloſet, and could not open the Door above this wideneſs, and I looked in, and ſaw the Razour all in Blood, and my Lord lay on his Arm in this faſhion. I could not tell, Whether he was dead or no, but I thought it was not my buſineſs to ſtir him. Then my Lord Conſtable was Ordered to come and Scoure and Examine all the Servants.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Pray, Captain Hawley, where does the Caſement look into?

sp.speaker: Capt. Hawley.
sp.p: The Houſe, ever ſince I came to it, is juſt as it was; and the Houſe having ſetled, the Caſement won't open above thus far; and 'tis ſo low, and the Pales are 9 or 10 Foot high, that 'tis impſſible for any one to throw any thing out of the Window 3 Foot hardly. It is one of the horrideſt Reports that ever was heard of, and the unlikelyeſt thing, they cannot throw any thing out of the Window to be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I think it is not neceſſary to call any more Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Have they any thing to ſay further, on the other ſide?

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke.
sp.p: I deſire, my Lord, to call my Man.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Call your Man, for what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: M. Speke.
sp.p: My Lord, If your Lordſhip pleaſe, I will call my Man to prove, that I knew nothing of Mr Bradden's coming to me.

div.p: Then Mr. Speke's Man was Sworn.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Ask him, what you will?

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee Mr. Bradden with me?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Never but once, before that time he came to my Maſters Chamber, which was the night before he went out of Town; and when he came, after he had been there a little while, my Maſter Ordered me to get me ready to go in to the Country with him. And after I had been with him a little time, he got another to go with him, and ſent me home again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke.
sp.p: I was going to Bed, was I not?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes, you was.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Have you done of both ſides?

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke.
sp.p: Was it not a Surprize to me, when he came to me?

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How does he know that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke.
sp.p: I tell you, why, my Lord, I ask it; Becauſe when I go out of Town, I always tell him, to prepare himſelf.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: It was a Surprize to me; I knew nothing of it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, have you done now? Have you a mind to ſay any thing to the Jury, you that are of Counſel for the Defendants; or you, Mr. Bradden?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bradden.
sp.p: No, I will ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Have you, Mr. Speke?

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke.
sp.p: My Lord, I have proved it here, That I had no hand in what I am Accuſed of. It is put down in the Information, that I Conſpired, with Mr. Bradden, to endeavour to procure falſe Witneſſes. I have proved, I never had any hand at all in any thing of it. It was an Accidental thing, his coming to me; and it was a great Surprize to me, when he came; and I never concerned my ſelf in it more, than the Writing of that Letter: And I had no ill intent in it; I did it not deſignedly; for I knew nothing of his coming; and I had not writ the Letter, if he had not come to me. And 'tis plain, it was a Surprize, for I always give my Man notice, when I go out of Town, beforehand to prepare himſelf. I thought nothing at all of ill in the Letter: I writ it late at night, when I had been with ſome Company at the Tavern. And if he made me believe that to be True, which was not, I hope the Gentlemen of the Jury will conſider that. I have nothing to ſay of the thing, I did not concern my ſelf in it any further at all, than Writing the Letter, which I did not well know, what I Writ.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, have you any more to ſay, Mr. Speke?

sp.speaker: Mr. Speke.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Have you any more, Mr. Bradden?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bradden.
sp.p: My Lord, I have only this to ſay for my ſelf. It has not been proved directly, or indirectly, That I uſed any evil Arguments, to perſwade theſe Witneſſes to teſtify what was falſe; but I dealt with them with all the Candour, that any Perſon in the World could uſe; and uſed all the Caution that I could, to hinder them from ſpeaking any thing that is falſe. There has been nothing proved of evil Practice uſed by me; and I deſire the Gentlemen of the Jury to take no other notice of any thing that has been, or ſhall be ſpoken, but what has been Proved.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But becauſe Mr. Attorney has produced his proofs to manifeſt that this Lord murdered himſelf, I will take notice a little of it, becauſe it may have ſome good effect to undeceive ſome that have been impoſed upon. Not for my own ſatisfaction, I thank God I am ſatisfied, and ſo I believe are moſt honeſt men: but that ſilly people may not be impoſed upon by every buſie fellow for the future, that takes the liberty to run about and ſpread falſe News, and that men may be aware of ſuch fellows, and may not be decoyed any more by ſuch falſe pretences; it was therefore fit that Evidence ſhould be given of the truth of the Fact, that that Gentleman did murder himſelf. And the Evidence is this.

Beſides the Inquiſition, which was taken upon the Oaths of ſeveral perſons of Quality (as you hear upon the reading their Names, ſeveral of them were Eſquires, and men of Note) 'tis here alſo proved by the Teſtimony of his Servant that attended him, how he came to his untimely end. And, Gentlemen, I would obſerve, 'tis Sworn by his Servant, one that had lived ſix years with him, not an upſtart, or a wandring fellow, but one whoſe integrity and fidelity to my Lord was confirmed by ſix years experience of his ſervice. Then here is the Wardour that was at the Door, here's the Souldier, here's the Maſter of the Houſe, who are all the perſons that probably can give any account of the matter, and they tell you poſitively that no one did go up and down, but this Frenchman, who was his Valet de Chambre. And the Wardour tells you, that he coming to the Door, and knocking at the Door, and hearing no one Anſwer, did endeavour to open the Door, but it was ſo faſt by my Lords feet, that he could open it but a little, and looking in, diſcerned blood, and that made him make Acclamations, as the Wardour calls it, Orations, which brought all the people in the houſe thither, and they gave the ſame account that he does.

And 'tis likewiſe fit to be taken notice of, that the window of this Cloſet looks into a private Yard, where no ſtrangers uſually come, and where no Coach could come; and that the Pales were ſo high, that in caſe a Man were deſirous to throw any thing out, it were impoſſible to caſt it above three Foot. And if there could no Coach at all come into the Yard, as it is plain there could not (for there is no door ſave only a back houſe door)
then this muſt needs be a lie, that was ſpread abroad. And 'tis beyond all peradventure true that my Lord of Eſſex did murder himſelf.

Now to have ſo great a truth as this to be perverted, and to reproach the Government with falſities, is the moſt malicious thing in the World. If in caſe the Law has made it penal for any man to ſcandalize any one private perſon as it has; and if it be by Law, much more penal to ſcandalize a Noble Man: how much more ought it to be, when the King and the whole Government is thus ſcandalized.

Now to come to the Fact, as near as I can recollect, I will give you an account of what Evidence has been given of the one ſide and of the other. But this I thought fit to premiſe, becauſe there will ſome Circumſtances fall out fit to be taken notice of in the Evidence, eſpecially about the Window in Captain Hawleys Yard and Houſe, which may be cleared this way.
In the firſt part of the Evidence for the King, they call a Witneſs to prove the Earl of Eſſex's Commitment, which is part of the Inducement in the Information.

But for the Information it ſelf, there is this Evidence. Firſt, Evans he comes and tells you, how that he had heard at the Cuſtom-houſe from Edwards the Father of this Boy, as though there had been a report came to him from home, at ten a Clock that morning my Lord of Eſſex cut his Throat, of a Razour thrown out of my Lord of Eſſex's Window; That he came to him in the afternoon again, and in the afternoon told him, He had examined the matter further, and his Boy confirmed the truth of it. He ſays that after this, Mr. Bradden and another man, one Mr. Hatſell, if I am not miſtaken in his name, came to the place where he was in Eſſex, and there they had ſome diſcourſe about my Lord of Eſſex's death, and there Hatſell took out of his Pocket a printed Copy of the Inquiſition; and Mr. Bradden was then in the Room, but he ſays he thinks Mr. Bradden at that time took no manner of notice of it, but walked about the Room. But he ſaies the Inquiſition was read while he was in the Room, and Evans ſaid ſomething about the report he had heard, which did ſeem to contradict that Inquiſition. But ſome time after, he ſaies that he being at the Coffee houſe, Bradden and Edwards came to him into the Coffee-houſe, and there they began to talk: Edwards ſaid, that Bradden had been with his Child to examine him, to bear Teſtimony about flinging the Razour out at Window. He was very full of the word [Matter], and toſſed that to and fro, but at length the Subſtance of his Matter was, that Report of the Boys, and he adviſed them to forbear talking any farther to him about the Matter, for it might do Edwards and Bradden both an injury; and he had read the Inquiſition which was quite contrary. That was all he could ſay.

Then comes Edwards, and the Subſtance of what he ſays is this, That he firſt heard it from his Family, and afterwards the Boy confirmed the truth of it; but then afterwards he heard he had denyed it, which was after Bradden had been there to inquire about it. And then he ſays Bradden came to him again, and then he had got a Note dictated by himſelf and not by the Boy, but at firſt he tendred it to the Boy, and the Boy refuſed to put his hand to it, and Mr. Bradden came again another time (though he was told the Boy had denyed it as he heard) and then the Boy did ſet his Hand. This is the Subſtance of what Edwards ſays. He does ſay indeed, the Boy uſed to tell lies very often, to make excuſes when he played Truant, and that his Family told him, the Boy was often guilty of telling of lies.

Then the next Evidence is the Evidence of the Boy himſelf. He it ſeems is thirteen years of Age: certainly any man that had been of an upright mind and Conſcience, as Mr. Braddon pretends to be, and would have you Gentlemen think him ſo; would have it thought that he was full of honeſty and integrity to the Boy, when he baited his Hook with a Text of Scripture, about the danger of telling a Lye, and, Have a care, Child, of telling a Lye; if he had done no more, but given him this advice, it had been worthy of commendation: but when the Boy had refuſed to ſign it, for him to go and make ſuch a ſtir without examining further into the particulars, but only taking a ſlight report from ſuch a Child, and to make ſuch a diſturbance in the Nation, and ſuch a Noiſe not only here but abroad, as this has done, ſure argues neither uprightneſs nor Conſcience. Had the Boy ſtood in it and perſevered in it, it had become him, in regad of the tenderneſs of the boys age, to have been more inquiſitive into Circumſtances, before he gave ſuch credit to what he ſaid, as to make all this adoe.

But what ſays the Boy, when he comes here, he is now upon his Oath, and he tells you, He did tell his Mother ſo at firſt, and he did tell Mr. Braddon ſo at firſt; but afterwards when his Siſter ſpake to him, and bid him be ſure to tell nothing, but what was truth, then he ſaid truly, it was not truth. He tells you Mr. Braddon offered him the Paper to ſign, but he would not ſign it; and being asked the Queſtion, Why he would not ſign it: He ſays, becauſe it was not true; and being asked, Whether Braddon had notice of this, the Mother and Siſters all tell you, He had notice the Boy had denyed it.

How came Mr. Braddon, what Authority had he to take this Examination? He is no Juſtice of Peace, no Magiſtrate, that had any authority to take Examinations. What concern had he in it more than other people? The Boy could tell him there were abundance of people there beſides himſelf, though it was a Lye he told then, and that the Girl told now. Why did not he ſtay to have it confirmed by ſome of thoſe people? Why did not he carry theſe Children before ſome Magiſtrate, or Juſtice of Peace, ſome body that had authority to take Examinations? There was a Spirit that prevailed with Mr. Braddon to engage and make a ſtir in this buſineſs; and you may eaſily gueſs what a kind of Spirit it was which gave him this authority that he had not before.

Gentlemen, Another thing is this, 'Tis plain, and the Boy now ſwears it directly, That whereas he put it into his Information, How that he told him he was going to ſee my Lord Brandon Gerrard's Lodgings, but now he is upon his Oath, he ſwears directly, he never told him any ſuch thing, and yet he hath put it into the Paper he made him ſign.

He tells you a ſecond time, Mr. Braddon came to him, which was after the Boy had refuſed and declared himſelf unwilling, and that then he was perſwaded by Mr. Braddon, who told him there was no harm in it; if there be any harm, it would be to him, and not to the Boy, and ſo by vertue of that, he inſinuated himſelf, and got the Child to ſign that Paper, which is every Tittle of it falſe, as the Boy now ſwears directly. And he tells you, How he was impoſed upon by Mr. Braddon, pretending there was no harm to him, all the harm would come to himſelf, and by reaſon of theſe Inſinuations he was prevailed upon, to put his Name to that which was notoriouſly falſe.

The next Witneſs (to make it appear that it was notoriouſly falſe, not only by the Boy himſelf, but by other Circumſtances) is Hawkins the Miniſters Son, Dr. Hawkin's Son of the Tower. And he tells you, I play'd Truant as well as he that day, and I ſaw the King and the Duke at the Tower, and when I had ſeen them I went about as they did, and afterwards I went home, and there came a Report, that my Lord of Eſſex had cut his Throat, which made me go back again to the Tower, and there was I a conſiderable time gaping among other people, and there did I ſee this Boy Edwards; when he came there, I was there; I was there all the time that he was there, and we went out of the Tower together, and there was no ſuch thing, nor any pretence or ground for ſuch a ſtory. And Edwards himſelf being asked the Queſtion, upon his Oath, doth likewiſe ſay, Hawkins was with him all the time there. So that that ſhews not only by what the Boy ſays, that it was falſe, but it is alſo proved falſe by the Teſtimony of this other Witneſs Hawkins.

Then next comes Mr. Blathwait who was preſent when Mr. Braddon was before the King, and what does he ſay? He ſays there was the Boy fetched, and the Girl fetched, and all perſons examined there, and then 'tis told him, all the Boy had ſaid to him was falſe, and it was told him with all its Circumſtances. So that notice ſufficient, if you will believe Mr. Blathwait, was given to this Mr. Braddon, That the Boy had denyed it then, as he had before to his Siſter: So he knew it was falſe.

But what does Mr. Bradden do now?
